reviews/0/text: We walked along the riverfront on the Porto side, enjoying the views across the river, of the barges, and of the bridge, but especially of the multi-coloured housing above the cafes and restaurants. We then sat and had lunch listening to street performers and watching the world go by! There is also a market area (tourist stuff basically) at the bridge end, as well as the occasional artisan shop.
reviews/1/text: We headed here first when we arrived as it was lunchtime. A large selection of restaurants all with a view of the bridge and river and lots of people watching.
reviews/1/title: Very buzzy with lots of lovely restaurants
reviews/2/text: Vibrant and busy area with lots of street performers, restaurants, bars, street market and of course walking next to the mighty Douro River with boat trips galore and also a fantastic view of the Ponte de Dom Luis 1 bridge.
reviews/3/text: Spend time on the quay side in the morning before the crowds arrive to enjoy the views of the bridges and the boats.  Return later for the buzz, music, entertainment.
reviews/4/text: if you want to dine at a popular  restaurant you must reserve. otherwise, perfectly great for sunset. the vibe is pleasant party atmosphere to enjoy the river Douro.
reviews/5/text:
The Riberira district of Porto gives you indefinite photo opportunities - it’s soooooo picturesque.

Remember that you can take the many pictures from both sides of the river and from the Luis I bridge.

When your phone runs out of ‘juice’, it’s time for a drink and a snack in one of the countless bars and restaurants in the district … and on the other side of the river you’ll find the numerous portwine houses ready to serve a glass or five.
reviews/6/text: The avenue along the Duoro river where you can take a boat tour of the Duoro. Lots of very good restaurants and naturally souvenir stores. Great for people watching. Also quite a few street performers, mainly singers.
reviews/7/text: It can be said that Cais da Ribeira is the center of Porto and not only of its nightlife, In fact, many of the short cruises along the Douro river depart from here and tourists gather here to stroll and enjoy the view of the river and Gaia on the other bank. The transit of tourists between the two banks of the river through the lower deck of the Dom Luís I bridge is uninterrupted and intense. So we did too strolling, taking pictures and stopping in the several cafes, bars and restaurants that are present on one side of the road reserved for pedestrian only. Here in the evening the good music of the street performers helps to make the stay in this crowded area pleasant, Definitely not to be missed if you visit Porto.
reviews/7/title: The center of Porto and not only of its nightlife
reviews/8/text: I did the 6 bridges cruise with the Yellow  bus hop on / off. It was the Perfect weather day, just a fantastic day all around.
reviews/9/text: I guess everyone has to wander along here and have a drink watching the world go by. Some really good musicians and singers. Bars a tad expensive in comparison with others. Super Bock beer in most. Taste the wine if you can before you choose. One of the touristy bars served the worst rose I have ever had. It was orange and 4 euro and would have preserved a dead fish it was so toxic.
reviews/9/title: Nice views of the river, bridge and other side
reviews/10/text: I loved walking Cais da Ribeira! The restaurants were charming and it was fun watching the boats. People watching, eating delicious food and drinking wine make for a great relaxing day.
reviews/11/text: Great place to people watch as you nurse a coffee or glass of local wine. Does tend to be crowded in the afternoons and evenings
reviews/11/title: A must visit for the view and ambience
reviews/12/text:
Sitting with a glass of wine at one of the many little places there, watching thousands of people go by and looking up at the bridge can be an all day/night experience.
We loved everything about Porto.
reviews/13/text: Lovely area with small shops and restaurants.  A must when in Porto and great areas for some great photography.
reviews/14/text: No trip to Porto could be complete without a visit to Cais da Ribeira.  Teeming with hustle and bustle, lots of cafes, bars and restaurants, quirky shops.
reviews/15/text: Spent the beginning of our Portugal vacation here and could not have enjoyed it more. Between all the attractions & walking spaces it was easy to navigate. Anyone calling parts of this area a tourist trap are looking for criticism. We came to be trapped :)
reviews/15/title: Just visit, plenty to experience & see.
reviews/16/text: Combine a visit to the Cais da Ribeira with the Ponte de Dom Luis I bridge and Douro River. The area is really nice, offers a great vibe, has a lot of great restaurant and some great pastries (pastel da nata). Well worth the visit. In my opinion thsi area is the best Porto has to offer!
reviews/16/title: Combine a visit to the Cais da Ribeira with the Ponte de Dom Luis I bridge and Douro River
reviews/17/text:
Ribeira district is the riverfront of old town Porto which is right behind it in a maze of old narrow winding streets.
Ribeira is very popular with both, locals and tourists with many bars, restaurants, street performers,...etc. Walking it will reward you with great views of Douro and the iconic Dom Luis bridge. However, have in mind it's a high tourist area, so you can guess prices in establishments around are higher with lower service quality.
TIP: Great views of Ribeira district are from Vila Nova de Gaia right across or from the upper level of Dom Luis bridge.
reviews/18/text:
It’s one of those places you should visit when in Porto. The waterfront area is awash with restaurants and bars, all serving pretty much the same, but who cares, on a sunny day it’s lovely to stroll along by the river taking in the vibrancy of the area. 
From here you can purchase tickets for the 6 Bridge cruise. It’s not all about the waterfront area, head uphill and soon you’ll be amongst the old streets of Porto. It’s a great place to explore.
reviews/19/text: This area is very pretty as it lines the bank of the Duoro River with nice shops and restaurants.  Have lunch here and enjoy the ambience.

description: Clérigos Tower is the foremost undisputed landmark of Porto and a reference in the city's history. Clérigos Tower opened its doors in 1763, becoming the highest bell tower of Portugal, with over 75 metres. In 1753 the Italian architect Nicolau Nasoni was invited to design and build this magnificent Heritage, considered National Monument since 1910. The famous church was built in the eighteenth century, between 1732 and 1749 and this was the most emblematic work of the architect Nicolau Nasoni. Is one of the most beautiful temples of baroque feature, and a reference in the history of Porto. The Exhibitions allow to discover the history of the Brotherhood of Clérigos, admire pieces from the eighteenth to the nineteenth century, in painting, furniture, jewellery and vestment collections. Christus collection, on the 3 floor, is a trip through time and space where art and religion complement each other.

reviews/0/text:
Nice views of the city - the 225 steps up are not difficult - of course, it also depends on your age and overall fitness. We were told later that going up a nearby hotel which has a restaurant at the top would yield the same results and you could use the nominal entrance fee money at the tower for a beer at the restaurant. 

Overall, these old monuments need some funds too so didn't mind paying the fee.
reviews/0/title: If you have time, do go up - get a better idea of the town
reviews/1/text: You can visit both the church and tower at the same time. There is no lift to the top of tower, only stairs which are very cramped in places. Once you reach the top there are nice views but there is no management of the number of people going up and down the tower which resulted in overcrowding at the top.
reviews/1/title: Nice but not worth a trip
reviews/2/text: Well worth a visit. Fantastic views and great value for money. Fantastic experience and glad we visited this wonderful tower.
reviews/3/text: Towering above the city you cannot miss this tower, the steps for the first part of the climb are very good but the last few steps to the very top are quite narrow and when people are wanting to come down it does get a bit tight, but persevere and you will be delighted with the views.
reviews/4/text: Great views - 225 steps up a very narrow staircase. Did it first week of January and little to no crowds. Get your stamp that you completed the climb on the back of the guide when you are done!
reviews/4/title: Fun little 225 steps for a great view!
reviews/5/text:
We visited on a busy Sunday which we expected the weather wasn’t great but we queued for our tickets and came back half hour later , this gave us chance to admire the interior of the church from below . The museum is ok and the tour gave a higher perspective of the interior of the church before climbing the tower itself . 
The stairs themselves are narrow as expected but not in a continuous spiral which for me massively helped as usually I get quite dizzy in these situations. There are people descending at the same time so be prepared for that , we had booked the 11.30 slot which was perfect as when we did reach the top the church bells was ringing across the city , part of the tower goes through the bells so if desired you could deafen yourselves by being in the bell room when they rang ! 
Lovely views very cramped up there as other people had stated but I appreciated the experience, I feel like bags should be made to be kept in a locker or a clocke room as the likes of backpacks doesn’t help the small spaces . 
All in all definitely worth a visit .
reviews/6/text: The Clérigos Church is a Baroque church whose peculiar characteristic is to have a particularly tall bell tower, the Torre dos Clérigos. Vaguely inspired by the bell towers that can be seen in Tuscany, with its six floors and 76 meters high, the Torre dos Clérigos, is the main symbol of the city and visible from several points of the same. The decision whether to pay admission to the tower and climb the 240 steps to the top is a personal one.
reviews/7/text: We saw this church on a walking tour and decided to return and explore in our own time.  As expected, visiting the church is monetized.  You can have a light show experience for several euro, or visit the tower (walk- up only) for another few euro.  I decided to only visit the interior of the sanctuary itself.  There are beautiful frescoes and sculptures, as well as a crypt.  It is worth a visit. The exterior opposite the bell tower is stunning.
reviews/8/text: Built in the mid 750's, this baroque tower of the Igreja dos Clerigos church is the tallest in Porto. Offers an amazing view of the city and the Duoro river. It has 225 steeps to the top so since i have a bad knee, needless to say i didn't climb it.
reviews/9/text: We visited this church and tower as it was very close to our accommodation. The ticket for an adult is E6 and kids under 10 go free. The way everything is organised was very smart. You follow the signs and pass through the church first - I found it very beautiful inside. Then the path takes you to a small gallery room. Then another room with Jesus Christ artefacts. After that you reach to a point where you need to show your tickets and then the proper climbing starts. The stairs were  narrow, so be prepared to wear good shoes and do stops to meet people. Once you reached the top the view was magnificent. Do this tour on a day with good visibility. There is info giving you an idea how tall the tower is. It’s a bit windy up there, so make sure you are dressed properly too. We spent about 30min observing the city from each corner.  A well worth money for what we got! Highly recommend as an extra bit to the main attractions Porto offers.
reviews/9/title: A beautiful church with a tower
reviews/10/text: Advisable to pre-book your visiting time (which usually means you need to come back at a later time that day), as spaces are limited, and so is the space once you get to the top! Once you have your ticket and slot, you enter via the fast track line and then follow a route that takes you via the church, elevated above, and some exhibitions. you don't get to see these on the way down, so if it is of interest, stop on the way! Once at the top, views are good. Worth the visit if you have the time and to see a different perspective of the city.
reviews/11/text:
The tower in a good day will give you a good view of the buildings across the city as well as the river. 
There are a lot of stairs and entry is timed by ticket. The man at the ticket desk is the only person who has been rude during our visit. He clearly should not be customer facing! I heard him being rude to other customers it wasn’t only me.
So the review level of 5 is for the view from the tower not for the ticket desk personnel….
reviews/11/title: Good view but sadly the ticket desk man was rude
reviews/12/text:
We've been to Porto several times ans finally seized the opposition to visit Clerigos with no queues.
We booked our time slot and returned half an hour later, perfect.
The church was beautiful and we really enjoyed taking in the architecture.
However the tower was really quite chaotic, people with bags coming past you and there was no room for them to pass. It's a free for all, no room to get out at the top so I had to queue to get one photo then back to struggling my way down.
Not enjoyable for a bit of a view at the top which you can get for free and much easier at many other spots in Porto. Don't do this especially if you are claustrophobic.
reviews/13/text: Visit also the park on the square beside the church and visit the local cafes and places to eat at great prices!
reviews/14/text: Having read the reviews I was unsure whether we should bother with the Tower but was glad we did. We queued for a short time around 4pm and were asked to come back for 5pm. Beautiful church interior and good views of Porto from the top of the tower, particularly enjoyed the signage which showed the main buildings/points of interest that you could see from the top.
reviews/14/title: Views of Porto and a beautiful church interior
reviews/15/text:
This beautiful Baroque tower dates back to 18 c when it was built by the same name Church. Today it is one of Porto landmarks.
However, I strongly agree with Nashville fellow traveler below.
Do go visit the Church - it is free, beautiful and usually no wait.
Skip the tower - it is waiting and paying. If you're for the views, just 10 min walk is Miradouro da Vitoria -no wait and great views.
reviews/15/title: Beautiful tower, but skip the climb
reviews/16/text:
We arrived at 11:00 a.m., stood in line for tickets until 11:30 a.m., stood around waiting for our noon entry time, toured most the facility by 12:30 p.m., but then stood in line to access the tower for 30 more minutes. After climbing to the top, we took a couple of panoramic pictures of Porto, walked back down, and exited the building at roughly 1:30 p.m. in the afternoon. That’s a 2.5-hour commitment for a church interior that’s no more impressive than others in town, and a view that can be had for free elsewhere.

You’d better REALLY want to see Clérigos Tower and be willing to lose 2.5 hours from your day! My advice is to skip this time suck altogether, see the interior of nearby Ingreja de São José das Taipas for free (which is nearly as impressive and only a 3-minute walk west), and get your stellar city views from the top of the Dom Luís I Bridge instead of this overrated tower. Take my advice!
reviews/17/text:
Definitely worth a visit, the church and museum are  included in the price of the ticket along with the tower.
The views from the tower are nice but it was extremely crowded, it is a very small space.
reviews/18/text: This tower was pretty as was the church it sits against but the best features are the views of Porto from the top.  Definitely worth the climb up the steep stairs.
reviews/19/text: Excellent view of the whole city from the up. Going to the tower you are allowed to see some other things and get to know the history of the Clerigos church and other monuments.  If you are really lazy it's not necessery for you to go there but anyway I thinks it's worth it.

reviews/0/title: Fascinating building, interesting history and informative, witty guide
reviews/1/text: Beautiful palace that is still used. You gave to visit with a tour guide. We chose to book on the day but spaces get booked quickly so i would recommend booking in advance. The tour guide was very good BUT there are too many people in the group, we had around 50. There are many groups touring at the same time so it does get very crowded. Still worth a visit.
reviews/2/text:
We had pre-purchased tickets online, but still had to queue with everyone else to be allocated a tour slot. On the day we went, the two tours in English were at 11am and 11.45am, nothing in the afternoon, so we were pleased we had made it the first stop of our day as we had about 20 minutes to wait for the 11am tour by the time we had got to the ticket desk.
The tour itself only lasts about 35 minutes but is well worth it; our guide was very entertaining indeed - a great actress! - and the building itself is definitely worth seeing as a whole but especially the stunning Arab room, the last room of the tour. I also really liked the courtroom.
When we left, it was noticeable how much longer the queue for the ticket office was!
reviews/3/text: The guide make difference. Our experience was a waste of time. Make sure you get some information during the visit or be prepared in advance. I am the type of person that need to learn from history. Would had been great for a guided visit presented as some kind of story. Plan to visit wineries which do have historic interesting stories with less tourists traps… Different younger visitors interest should be a concern to touristic responsible of Porto. I hope this help you guys previous you’re precious time invested in discovering our history.
reviews/4/text: We were staying a 5 minute walk from the Bolsa Palace. We were lucky to arrive at 10.40 and the next English tour was 11 and there was still places. The palace itself is lovely. However the tour is quite short at 30 minutes and the guide was rushing along. She didn't wait until people got to the next room. Once she was there she started giving her talk. I felt as the tour went on she was talking even more quickly. Having said that I'm glad we visited it. It is 12 euro admission and you have to take the tour. The tours run in lots of different languages at different times of the day.
reviews/4/title: Worth seeing but guided tour rushed
reviews/5/text:
Be warned, this is only open to guided tours.  You cannot just wander at your own pace.
The guided tours occur every half hour in a different language each time, and so it might be several hours before the next tour in your language.
In our case, we began queuing at 1050 and could see the signs saying the next English tour was at 1100.  When we finally got to the front, the single person serving took great pleasure in informing us that we had just missed the English tour by three minutes, we were not allowed to catch up or go unaccompanied, and that the next English tour was three hours later at 1400.  
Several visitors ahead of us in the queue had been purchasing tickets for the Portuguese/Spanish tours in half an hour and one hours time respectively, and visitors behind us in the queue had also been after the English version and were disappointed.  Yet the staff hadn’t seen fit to do a queuebusting “Is anyone for the English tour at 1100 please make yourself known” sort of announcement.  So we ended up making other plans for what to do in a rainy day. 
If you do manage to get in, I’m sure it’s very good.  But as above, be warned about the tour timings.  Apparently the language schedule isn’t published in advance, but rather the first ticket sold for a particular time specifies the language that that time slot will be.
reviews/6/text: The former Stock Exchange in Porto is a beautiful building right in the center of the Old Town.The rooms are nicely decorated and the Arabian Room is a piece of art.
reviews/7/text: An amazing building rich with history. It has some amazing architecture with a huge granite staircase as well as some intricate woodwork on the floors and walls. No longer being used as a chamber of commerce you can now follow a tour around the building. It took quite a while to queue for a ticket. Maybe better to buy online.
reviews/7/title: Gorgeous building in the centre of Porto
reviews/8/text: This is a must not miss. impressive on the inside, beyond words. worth filling yoru eyes and mind with so much creativity.
reviews/8/title: gorgeous visit of history and architecture
reviews/9/text: Great tour from Pedro. Took us around the palace mixing fact and humour. Very knowledgeable and passionate about his job. Would recommend.
reviews/9/title: Great tour with a stunning finish.
reviews/10/text: We booked a tour at this "palace" based on the Rick Steves book recommendation.  We were pretty disappointed in the amount of time it took to stand in line to get the tickets to then have to come back for the tour an hour later.  The guide was hungover and had yelled too much the night before so he was hard to hear.  The rooms and tour were incredibly boring except the Arabian room.  Unless you are here for a week and are bored this was a waste of half a day in a town with lots of other things to see and do.
reviews/10/title: Booked based on Rick Steve's recommendation
reviews/11/text: The palace or the museum are not the main tourist attractions in Porto. You will find everything you love about travel, from restaurants, fine wines to beautiful beaches, interesting buildings, bridges, views and much more. If you want to visit Porto, just don't make a list of must-see tourist attractions. It doesn't work here
reviews/11/title: don't make a list of must-see tourist attractions.
reviews/12/text: The tour lasts about 30 minutes and you'll need to watch the schedule to know when the next tour in your language begins.  We purchased tickets in advance and had to redeem them at the counter, the next tour (in English) was 30 minutes later and after receiving tickets, you can leave the building but must return at least 5 minutes before your scheduled tour begins.  Sadly, there were non-English speakers on our tour who kept talking in their language.  Perhaps someone in their party knew English and was interpreting which made it difficult to hear the tour guide.  The most impressive part was the last room and some tid-bits of knowledge about government and architecture.  The guide was good.  He had a polite delivery of speech with small doses of jokes which made it engaging.  Another draw is that this attraction is low-budget and affordable.
reviews/13/text: Breath taking construction with beautiful gold ceilings, pillars, lovely stained glass, huge rooms, with a lot of history. I suggest a guided tour because there is a ton of history in this building and you must see the flag on the ceiling that represents USA or your country.
reviews/14/text: The former Porto Stock Exchange that is now a historic building. They have guided tours but the line to buy tickets was too long. You can buy tickets in advance.
reviews/15/text: You'll be in and out in 1 hour... once you book your tour time. The ticketing system is dumb, where you get in line to buy a ticket, but then you have to pick a tour time. You go through a separate entrance once you come back for the tour. It lasts about one hour and you can take loads of photos. Our guide was extremely informative and the history was pretty cool.
reviews/16/text:
Worth a visit but be careful not to spend longer in the queue than you do on the tour!
Be mindful that you queue to buy a ticket which won't get you necessarily on the next tour, you will choose the language when you buy your tickets and they confirm the times available. We bought our tickets around 9.30am and queued for maybe 15 minutes. The next available tour was 10.15am so we went and got a coffee. When you return for your tour don't join the ticket queue but go into the entrance hall (we went in via the exit) then head to the inner courtyard, somebody will check your ticket just as you go through the door to the courtyard. The tour was informative and entertaining. It is worth the 10 euro price. When we came out at around 10.45am the queue for tickets was massive so suggest getting in early. I can't see any advantage to buying tickets on line, as at Oct 22 the online option doesn't let you chose a date and time, you still have to queue to book which language tour you need and check availability.
reviews/17/text: Amazing Tour of this palace to commerce. Each room on the tour had a unique style and history. As with so many historic locations we toured, this felt very rushed due to the crush of other groups. That said, the architecture was breathtaking even without being able to hear all the details. One notable problem with this site was a lack of restrooms given how many people were in the building.
reviews/18/text: Well worth the 10 Euros for the tour. It is clear the money that Porto had in its heyday. The Arabian Room is everything it's reported to be.
reviews/19/text:
This attraction is in urgent need of an update to its archaic booking system!!

We had to queue for about 30 minutes... It was around half way through queuing that we turned a corner and saw a screen showing which tours were available in which language. The next available English language tour was 2 hours later (!) and the screen showed it was at 88% capacity. By the time we reached the till we were told it was full (though the screen didn't update to show 100% capacity). When I queried the system and asked if online booking would have secured an English tour at a time of my choosing, to my surprise the lady working there told me I would still have had to queue to secure a tour in the language I wanted! Totally bonkers!! Why would they not update to a live booking system? 
We ended up on a Spanish tour... Didn't understand a word but we got to see inside the building which was beautiful.

reviews/0/text: This Gothic Cathedral have very intricate interior design and located on an amazing hilltop that offers great view of Porto. Do not miss seeing this Romanesque building.
reviews/1/text: What I liked about this cathedral are the ceramic panels on the inside walls and the view of the city from the top of the structure. The cathedral is, after all, listed among Porto’s World Heritage sites. My recommendation is that it may deserve a visit if you spend 2 days or more in Porto. Roaming around the city is perhaps more fun than visiting this cathedral if you have 2 days or less.
reviews/1/title: The view of the city from the top is great!
reviews/2/text: It is rather a big climb up from the Riverside to the cathedral, but the views are great - and then you go inside the cathedral itself! Firstly, the €3 entrance fee is really reasonable as you see the cloisters, cathedral itself, tower area and treasury for that. The cloisters are amazing - certainly we have never seen anything like them before - beautiful stonework plus azuljeros makes for a stunning combination. The cathedral itself is quite plain in some parts but the area around the main altar is beautiful and an interesting mixture of decorative styles. The rose window is lovely. The treasury is small but quite interesting; on the tower level there are two huge azuljeros pictures. Definitely well worth a visit.
reviews/3/text: Not as grand and as imposing as  some other Cathedrals but still lots to admire as you wander around the different areas and take in its history, don't forget to walk up the steps to the top of the tower for views across the city.
reviews/4/text: Nice Place to go, great views really a place to go. Entrance only 3 euros each. Afterwards we went down tochtje city going through the narrow streets.
reviews/5/text: We went into 2 churches in Porto and this is worth paying the Euro3 to go in.  The architecture is really beautiful and when we visited, it was not busy.  So we had all the time and atmosphere to enjoy the architecture, tiles and scenery it offered.  It’s a working church.  I like the visit a lot and I’m not religious.
reviews/6/text:

A visit to the Estadio do Dragao (the Stadium of the Dragon) home of Portuguese powerhouse FC Porto was somewhat of a cathartic experience for me, helping put several seemingly cursed aspects of my life as a football fan behind me.
 
After repeated failed attempts to see my team play away in Europe, usually in spectacular circumstances, Porto held a somewhat unique place as the only European team I'd ever tried to attend a game of whom the curse also applied - 2018 had seen me arrive in the City on a Saturday night in preparation for a cup game on the Sunday...only for said game to get moved to Saturday afternoon. I still enjoyed my trip to Portugal's second city, and took in their excellent stadium tour and museum, but it remained something of a sticking point with me.
 
Cue my team drawing Porto in the Europa League, it seemed like either the perfect opportunity to end 2 curses at once, or alternatively condemn the city of Porto to a meteor hitting it.
 
Now, admittedly I was working in different circumstances, but I do know from my previous visit that attaining tickets for Porto home games is easily enough done. They sell them online (in what appears to be a fairly user-friendly setup) or you can purchase them from any of the FC Porto stores in the city. Availability obviously depends on the game, for 90% of them you can probably walk in quite easily, but don't expect to rock up on the day of games against Benfica, Sporting, and maybe Boavista (I'm not sure about this one but it is the local derby) and pick up a ticket. Prices are standard for Europe, expect to pay between €25-35 for a ticket.
 
Getting to the Stadium is very simple - a few of Porto's excellent metro lines have a stop literally called 'Estadio do Dragao' and most of these lines also stop at all the main tourist points across the city too. I'll admit I wasn't keeping time but it can't be any longer than 20 minutes from the Trinidade metro hub.
 
Now, being an away fan I was somewhat restricted (rather unnecessarily I feel as the Porto fans didn't appear to really be any trouble at all and were actually quite welcoming) with regards to pre-match experience, but from what I could see there were a few street vendors between the large shopping centre that sits adjacent to the stadium, and a few trucks selling the delightful local Super Bock lager. Sadly we got herded straight in, although again commendations to the local police who actually handled things well and build up a fairly decent rapport with fans as opposed to leading in with batons.
 
When inside the stadium, the catering was, well hard to call. There was quite an extensive menu on the wall, though the vast majority of it wasn't available to us in the away end. Limiting us to hot dogs, crisps and drinks. I'm not sure if this was a deliberate move on Porto's part thinking that's all Scottish fans would want, but I can confirm I am a big fan of a Bifana, and everyone loves Pizza, but this may have been an ordering issue so can't say for certain. The hot dog and drink I got was fairly priced and of good enough quality. In the same concourse there was a small stand selling official FC Porto merchandise.
 
Now, one of the reasons do Dragao had been so high on my list of places I wanted to visit was that it was the first high profile European stadium I can remember being built in my lifetime, at least that I was aware of. This meant that while it still holds a fairly cracking maximum capacity at just over 50,000, it isn't quite the soulless cavern that a lot of older European arenas can prove to be. Indeed, while the away fans are lodged in one of the upper tiers, due to the modern design you still get a very good view of the entire pitch.
 
Likewise the seating is comfortable and spacious (typically for a game I spent on my feet) and in general it's one of the finest venues in terms of design, quality and upkeep I've had the pleasure of taking in a game in. Genuinely excellent modern sporting amphitheatre.
 
If there was but one complaint I had, it was the lack of presence and atmosphere of the Porto fans, however I'm gonna give them the benefit of the doubt on this one. Kicking off at 6pm local time is a pretty awful idea on UEFA's part, meaning a lot of potential ticket buyers attended late, if at all as working hours in Portugal can run well past this. It's poor planning that ruins the spectacle, and there were still hundreds of Porto fans working their way inside minutes into the game. I suppose I'll just need to attend a game in the home end sometime to really see the Porto fans!
 
With all of this said, I'd still 100% advocate a trip to the Estadio do Dragao, regardless of if you’re a home fan or in the away end. Genuinely one of the best Stadiums I've attended in all of Europe and beyond.

description: Always fresh, always at hand The past is revisited in the new Bom Sucesso Market, through the familiar colors and scents of fruit and vegetables. One can almost hear the market woman's catchy cries. Modern days are still filled with those scents and colors, but the Market has gone a step further by adding new delicacies and flavors. The place invites visitors to find out more about its history and about the road taken until the present day. In here all five senses are awakened. And at the end of a working day, this inviting and sensorial space is ideal for a snack among friends, ideal to share thoughts and dreams, or to revive old memories. Life can be smooth, even with abounding sensations. Matches your smile Bom Sucesso Market is a Babel made of costumes, routines and traits of people that are here, and people that arrive. There are shopping bags, and little gifts to be exchanged, there are offices closing new deals and opening new doors. There are local people enjoying the place, but also foreign faces, with different accents and languages, already so familiar. In between the hotel and the market area there is bustle and pauses punctuated with fleeting smiles and loud guffaws. We love this concept that becomes more meaningful when a smile flowers from a pair of lips, when people cross each other's paths in a place where so many things happen.

But the view was still pretty terrific (although, I would highly suggest going when the Sun is out). The climb was pretty manageable upwards - as one doesn't feel the steepness of the climb. But coming down, is where one would start to notice how steep the incline is and how tall the bridge actually is. Although it is steep, you won't really have to worry as it is very wide, and there are measures in place to ensure your safety. There will be a guide that brings you up and down the bridge. Parque da Cidade in Porto is the biggest urban park in Portugal and the ideal place to have a nice relaxed walk, do your workout, have a picnic or even some birdwatching.
Parque da Cidade, meaning city park, located on the western end of Avenida da Boavista, is one of the city’s lungs. Facing the ocean and with a direct access to Praia Internacional (the beach), the park, has 83 hectares of area and tries to replicate a rural ambience, and that’s why it’s classified as a “naturalist” style park. If you decide to go to the beach, try one of the surf schools based in, and around, Edifício Transparente, and take a look at “She Changes“, a  27-meter high floating sculpture by Janet Echelman

We were in Oporto in September, primarily to drink wine, and lots of it. On our first full day, we had arranged for a driver/guide, with the Concierge from our hotel in Vila Nova de Gaia, and our first stop was at Parque da Cidade do Porto. We entered just off of Avenida da Boavista, across from the Instituto de Neurociéncias, which was highly coincidental, as one of my wife’s hospitals is a world-renown neurological institute.

The Parque da Cidade do Porto is immense, and lovely, with a broad diversity. We walked along just one path, that took through formal gardens, and large lawns. Our guide indicated that it was the largest “city park” in Portugal, and I believe that easily.

Though we walked but a small portion, we came upon ducks, geese and swans (plus an errant seagull, or two), and saw rabbits and squirrels galore. It was almost like walking through a nature preserve. One observation was that there were very few people in the park, though given its size, maybe they were all just elsewhere?

It was a wonderful way to start a day of exploration.

reviews/1/title: Beautiful church in Rua Santa Catarina!
reviews/2/text: It’s really weird to see this incredibly ornate tiled church in the middle of a busy modern shopping street! Unfortunately we were unable to go in as there was a service.
reviews/3/text: This is arguably the most beautiful of all of the numerous chapels, and churches of Port. Go there! The hand-painted blue and white tiles (azulejos) on the outside are mind blowing!
reviews/4/text: Interesting building in Porto Portugal on the street of Old city . Accessible to tourists and found it while walking around old town. Enjoy
reviews/5/text: I read that the tiles are originally from Egypt and brought to Portugal by the Arabs, in the 13th century at the time of their invasion, which also helped shaped Portugal's culture. reviews/6/text: Tripadviosrs seems to be misleading when in Porto. Everything you love about traveling is sure to be found in Porto: from restaurants, wine tastings, to beaches, bridges and views. I find it bizarre to choose a wall as the main tourist attraction in Porto
reviews/7/text: We drove by this on our very quick tour of Porto. I I would have loved to stop and see the interior, but we couldn't spare the time because we had to get to the port wine cellars. reviews/7/title: In the blink of an eye.
reviews/8/text: We admired this Chapel from the outside as we were wandering around the city.  It really stands out with it's beautiful blue and white tiles.

reviews/10/text: This was one of my Porto destinations. The chapel is dedicated to St. Francis and St. Catherine. The azulejos depict the lives and deaths of these two saints.  The chapel is small and contains a relic, but I was unable to figure out whose relic it represents.
reviews/10/title: Worth the hike up the hill

reviews/12/text: The azulejos depict scenes of life of two Saint Catarinas, an amazing sight. The chapel itself is classic.
reviews/13/text:

Try to see it during both the day and at night when its lit up as it photographs very well at both times.

reviews/14/text:
A beautiful building, it doesn't compare to what you see up close !!!
Don't miss it, very close to the center
reviews/15/text: We took a quick look inside and the altar is beautiful. The outside is interesting and makes a good photo opportunity.
reviews/16/text: Impressive at first sight for the all over azuelo tiles on a wide variety ofsubjects but for us the effect soon wore off and the effect became too much, and detracted from the architeture overall. A curiousity rather than a must see.
reviews/16/title: The novelty effect of the all over blue soon wore off.
reviews/17/text: I must confess we did not visit inside this one, but primarily searched it out to look at the 16000 stunning blue azulejo tiles that decorate the exterior. A short walk from central Porto so easy to find and highly recommended.
reviews/18/text: This is a very pretty church with exquisite tile work on the outside, and it continues on the inside with other religious decorations.  It's modest size is pleasing, one is not overwhelmed.  Lots of good art here.

reviews/1/text:
We started our walking tour here the first day and ended up here in the evening the second. Beautiful square and all the wonderful Buildings surrounding it.
Only negitive is that they are doing major renovations around the statue at the far end so it was impossible to take in the entire 4-5 blocks from end to end.

reviews/2/text:
The Liberty square is one of Porto's main squares right in the city center. It occupies a huge block beneath the imposing City Hall towering at the northern end.
During our second visit to this great city this June it was under heavy subway construction, but its beauty is still visible and I remember it from our previous visit 9 y ago.
reviews/3/text: If you're in Porto and you don't even pass this square... such a shame. Although some buildings around it were being recently renovated it still impressed us. It has such a style. We'd been in Porto for a week and literally every day we were going back to our apartment through that square. At night or in the middle of the day it looks amazing!
reviews/4/text:
Currently this huge square is a total mess due to the construction of a new metro line, but it possible to imagine how it usually appears if you can ignore the wire fences and barricades.
Home to the most beautiful McDonalds in the world and the wonderful City Hall I am sure once the building work is completed it will once again be back to its original glory.
reviews/5/text: The Metro construction did indeed damage the perspective of this city center square, but it is grand with the City Hall at one end and a big statue in the middle.  Major streets pass through it.  Lots of big banks around and some big cafes.  Very historic.
reviews/6/text: Important square often very busy. However nearby are many important buildings and a fountain and it is a good reference point for meeting up. Good photo opportunities.
reviews/7/text:
Liberty Square is a product of the 1718 urbanization movement of Porto.,
In 1866 a monument honoring King Peter IV was erected in the square. Peter IV was not only King of Portugal,  he was also Emperor of Brazil.
He is holding the constitution he had fought for in the Liberal Wars.

reviews/8/text: Don't go now: it's all dug up for a new Metro station. Otherwise I would say that there are far more interesting places to be in Porto.
reviews/8/title: Ok but so-so on the world scene
reviews/9/text: This is the most important square as well as a city showroom and a famous meeting point for locals. The square is surrounded by the grandiose avenue; Avenida dos Aliados and by tall highly-decorated granite buildings (mostly hotels and banks). To the north is the stately town hall with its tall tower and to the south is the equestrian statue of King Pedro IV. A nice feature of this square is also the beautiful modernist facade of McDonald's that is worth seeing.
reviews/10/text: The Square (Praça da Liberdade) and the Avenue (Aliados) are the heart of the city. This is the local where the FC Porto fans used to celebrate the victory in the football championships or where happens public protests
reviews/11/text: There is a huge open space here, allowing you to appreciate the different buildings all around you. The town hall looks over this space, which also is a beauty.
reviews/11/title: Great Open space, watches over by the Town Hall
reviews/12/text: In the square, you can admire the architecture, nature, and passers-by, as well as take good photos. There is not much entertainment in the square itself, but many interesting places and cafes are within walking distance
reviews/12/title: An attractive place for taking photos
reviews/13/text: Nice wide square which I enjoyed scooting across & taking a few photos. However there are only a few restaurants at the bottom end, & not much else to do.
reviews/13/title: Nice to visit, though not much to do here
reviews/14/text: Liberdade Square is the centre of Porto, with among others, the town hall. In the side streets, a lot of local/artistic/... shops.
reviews/15/text: This square is very interesting. It is surrounded by famous buildings. There are several statues along the way. There is a large construction project in the middle right now which detracts from the beauty.
reviews/15/title: The most famous square of Porto
reviews/16/text: This entire area is so wide an elegant. I passed everyday and never got tires. Buildings are beautiful and very well preserved.
reviews/17/text: Praca da Liberdade  is located in the very heart of Porto. It is Porto’s main square. The creation of this square dates back to the beginning of the 18th century.  In the middle of the Square is a 10-meter bronze equestrian statue of King Pedro IV from 1862. At one end of Liberdade Square is Porto’s main artery, Avenida dos Aliados. It is flanked by modernist buildings from the beginning of the twentieth century,  the Town Hall and some of the city’s banks, numerous cafes and shops.  The square is large enough for a pleasant walk or to sit back and relax on one of the benches.
reviews/18/text:
A stunning City square, one of the most impressive in Europe; not for it's size but the hill it's built on. Surrounded by impressive buildings.
Perhaps it does not get so much sun, maybe that's why some people are not so keen on it.

reviews/12/text: One of the best and must do things in Porto. If you can just take a walk from the historic centre and end up at the river. Enjoy the view and serenity.

reviews/2/text: This is a stunning interior even without being able to see the main altar. reviews/8/text: Spent a solid 1 hour here, taking pictures and and taking in the beautiful chapels. There's a confusing sign in front that makes it seem like you can't take pictures, but we asked and the guy said no flash. The carvings are ornate and the tombs/crypts are quite extensive.
reviews/9/text:
What I liked about this Church is that it has wood everywhere inside. Never have seen anything like it. Gave it a 4 because it was almost toooo much. They have some history as part of an exhibit in the adjoining building with cripes in the basement.

reviews/10/text: Very unique and impresive art creation. The church is incredible and unique. Therefore it is highly recommended ( though the price is quite high).

reviews/13/text: This beautiful old church is in an area of Porto where many tourists have hotels and visit restaurants, near the river, so very convenient to visit. It was worth looking around inside, though the main altar is blocked off for renovation now.

reviews/0/text:
Prior to arriving in Porto by plane the owner of the AirBnB flat we had rented for our stay told us that the best way to get to our destination was via the Metro do Porto as there was a station a short walk away from the property. In the event she was right, although she didn't tell us that a change would be necessary at the Trindade station. Also because of our ignorance we paid a bit too much for our tickets on this first day. However after a couple of days experience we got used to the procedure of buying or topping up our tickets. 

The Metro proved to be an excellent and inexpensive way of getting around although at some times it was standing room only.
reviews/0/title: Great way to get around town
reviews/1/text: Spotlessly clean and a cheap and cheerful way to navigate around the city if you do not fancy walking. Airport transfer to/from the city is easy and only costs 2.75euro, ticket machines are easy to use so what is not to like about that.
reviews/2/text: Easy to use and inexpensive.  Also found that people who use the metro everyday to travel to work were very courteous to visitors.
reviews/3/text: On arrival at the airport I went to the tourist office and bought an Andante tour 3 card for €15. This is valid for 72 hours from the time of first activation at a station and is not rechargeable, ideal for a tourist. I also bought a single journey to Porto centre for 2€ as I didn’t want to activate my tour 3 card at that time. Firstly you will need to use the Metro to visit various locations. I walk a lot but please bear in mind Porto is quite hilly so a mix and match of walking and Metro is essential. The trains are clean, bright and very well maintained. The stations were spotless and due to the colour coding system they use I found it user friendly. Please remember you must scan your card at the beginning and end of the journey at the yellow topped pillars at all stations. The 72 hour card enables unlimited journeys within that time period, and if worth adding it’s one card per person.
reviews/3/title: User friendly and a pleasure to use
reviews/4/text:
If you are travelling alone or as a couple the Metro from Porto airport into the city center is very easy. A short walk downstairs from the airport at the exit, the machines translate into English and choose zone Z4 for Trindade Station at a cost of €2.75 per person. Validate the ticket before getting on.
This takes you into the top of the old town tourist area just to the north of Ponte Luis Bridge.
We had about a twenty minute wait sat on the tram and the journey is then just over 30 minutes. easy return from the same station.
reviews/5/text: Best way to move around the city. I used it from Campanha station to the one I was staying by. I went to the football stadium and back and then to the airport was also accesible
reviews/6/text: We love the Metro.  Easy to read the route maps, clean trains, clean stations, fast low cost transportation.  Only issue is we are "seniors" and not one person got up and gave us a seat on any of our experiences.
reviews/6/title: Metro is the way to transport yourself in Porto.
reviews/7/text: we had trouble figuring our how to use the machines to buy tickets and how to buy the rechargeable tickets. once we figured the machine out, it was a wonder way to get around. maps at every station. people are very polite and respectful. no one we saw trying to travel without paying. highly recommend this mode of transportation. the 24 hour rechargeable tickets can be worth it if you move around a bit in a 24 hour period.
reviews/7/title: easy to ride super clean and safe
reviews/8/text: Tripadvior will not help you when traveling to Porto. Everything you love about traveling is sure to be found here. From restaurants, wine tastings, to beaches, bridges and views. It is bizarre for me to choose the metro as the main tourist attraction in Porto
reviews/9/text:
The Portuguese Metro (Subway) systems in Lisbon and Porto are very modern, fast, frequent, and safe.  The cost for most rides is under 2 euro, and the tracks will get you to or near most of the more important tourist attractions.  

The majority of the underground stations are clean, and have an elevator or two, and some have escalators; all have stairs.

description: Casa da Musica was conceived to mark 2001, the year in which Porto was Cultural Capital of Europe, and it is the first new building in Portugal to be entirely dedicated to music - to the presentation and public enjoyment of music, to music education and to the creation of music. The project took shape in 1999 after the Rem Koolhaas & Ellen van Loon - Office for Metropolitan Architecture won the international architectural competition. Work began in 1999 on the site of Porto's former central tram garage on the Rotunda da Boavista, and Casa da Musica opened its doors to the public on April 15th , 2005. Casa da Musica was planned as a home for all types of music and it is not only part of the urban redevelopment of Porto but also part of a network of cultural facilities, for the city of Porto and for the wider world. Underlying it is an innovative and wide-ranging cultural project, which aims to make an exciting contribution to the national and international music scene, as an arena for all types of musical events - from classical music to jazz, from fado to electronic music, from great international productions to more experimental projects. Besides concerts, recitals and other types of performance, Casa da Musica also organises events for musicians and musicologists and invests in research into the origins of Portuguese music. In addition, it plays a very important role in music education. It is a cultural meeting point between music and other areas of artistic creation and knowledge, providing a space for all kinds of audiences and creators.

reviews/3/text: Located not far from the Torre dos Clérigos, this church, in the Baroque Rococo style, has the rare peculiarity of having been built adjacent to another existing church, the Igreja dos Carmelitas. To separate the two churches, a short space was left between them in which a house was built whose existence is not recognizable from the outside being only 1.5 m wide and for this reason called Casa Escondida do Porto. If the facade of the church, on which Santa Anna stands out, to whom the order was very devoted, is relatively similar to the other churches, what makes Igreja do Carmo readily recognizable is the large panel of azulejos, depicting scenes from the foundation of the Carmelite Order. By paying a really cheap entrance ticket, you can visit the church and then continue with a visit to the tourist circuit of the Order of Carmo. The circuit begins with a stop to a small catacomb and continues in a few rooms where you can admire several objects belonging to the order such as relics, books, ancient hospital instruments, paintings, sculptures and several other objects, leaving the chuch from a side door next to the azulejo at the end of the tour. Definitely worth a visit if you are in Porto for a few days.

However personally I preferred the much narrower pedestrianised Rua de Cedofeita ( not on Trip Advisor from what I can tell) which is quite a historic street and home now to a lot of independent shops and boutiques as well as plenty of cafes and bars. And interestingly my credit card got more punishment on this street than it did on Rua de Santa Catarina.
reviews/6/title: The main pedestrianised shopping centre in Porto. All chain stores cain be found here
reviews/7/text:
Nice street full of shops , cafe restaurants,  malls and more.

GPS Igreja de Santo Ildefonso you can't miss this street right next to this church/museum, 
the street is packed with people like ants.
It's an entertaining walk, and best thing there is the opportunity to buy bracelets made of Cork. 
C U AROUND
reviews/7/title: Close to all attractions,  good place to shop and watch performers.
reviews/8/text: Rua de Santa Caterina and the surrounding neighborhoods is the most important shopping area in the city. It functions as a pedestrian street and is ideal to take a walk on, not only for the sake of all shops but also because there are some nice sights on it such as Capela das Almas and exquisite Art Nouveau facades such as Café Majestic. It's located in the high part of town and starts at the Praca da Batalha and exteds as faras 1,5km north. There are many good shops on this street but do not miss the beautiful facade and interior of "A perola do Bolhao", an old grocery store located on one of the side streets; Rua Formosa.
reviews/9/text: Rua Santa Catarina is the busiest street in Porto, with many shops, cafes, and restaurants. My hotel was near this street, so I enjoyed spending my evenings here.
reviews/10/text: This is a pedestrian street where you have all the shops. Nothing special and very crowded almost all the time.
reviews/11/text:
This is a must see/do in Porto. An early version of Oxford street but with much more character & less commercial, although it's definitely becoming so.
Beautiful shops in beautiful buildings.
Lots of history.
reviews/12/text: Very nice street, quite busy, full of shops, cafes and restaurants. It's very nice just to have a walk there, enjoy its atmosphere, not to be in a rush. Most of this street is for pedestrians only, closed for a traffic.
reviews/13/text: I adore this street.  Great shopping, food, buskers and people watching.   All of the little cafes along the street tucked in between great stores and boutique make this street a great way to spend a day.  If you need anything from groceries to wine and port to clothes, gifts, baby items, you can pretty much find anything along this street.
reviews/13/title: Great way to spend an afternoon
reviews/14/text: This is the city's main shopping area and as you would expect is busy and bustling at all times of the day and night with lots going on. Mostly pedestrianised there are shops and restaurants of all descriptions to suit all tastes and pockets.
reviews/15/text: I strongly recommend walking on Rua de Santa Catarina! The street is adorable, charming! It has several stores, cafes and restaurants!
reviews/16/text:
Whether or not you are planning to do some shopping, a walk on Rua Santa Catarina is a must do in Porto! 

You’ll be able to find plenty of shops, coffeeshops and restaurants - including the marvelous Majestic. Make sure you stop there at least for a coffee or their home made pastry!

Also in front of the shopping center - don’t forget to take a picture of their street art on the wall at the entrance in the building!
reviews/17/text: Every city has such a chick street with a lot of shops,  restaurants and for Portugal obviously igrejias (churches). You could feel the atmosphere of the city here. Just have a walk from one side to an other, stop to have a dinner and do small shopping.
reviews/18/text:
A vibrant and beautiful street with nice shops, restaurants, malls... it’s a good place for wandering. 
Capela das Almas ( a stunning church with blue coloured tiles on the outside walls ) and the iconic café Majestic are located there.
Nothing really special but if you want to shop, it’s the place to go in Porto.
reviews/19/text: If you wanna do the shoping go there. The street is full of shop with variety of products. You can find some good restaurants there too

reviews/0/text: So I walked into the church hoping to see some of it's historic interior when mass had just began.  Out of respect, I decided to stay at least through prayer.  The church as packed (no seating, I found a fold-able chair in the rear).  Tourists filed into the church in waves and it was a tad disruptive.  It's worth a visit and it's free.  Just be mindful of services -- the locals attend and fill up the place.
reviews/1/text:
Igreja dos Carmelitas-dates back to the 18th century in Baroque-Rococo style. 
The most interesting fact is that Carmo Church is twinned with the Carmelite Church, separated by a very narrow house built to make all contact impossible between nuns and monks. 
From the Praça de Gomes Teixeira you can see a nice panel of blue and white tiles designed by Silvestro Silvestri. 
note: free entrance
reviews/2/text:
In addition to the beautiful Church tiled exterior wall ( we did not go in either) there is a square with a fountain across the street in front of the University, Praca de Lisboa, a square to what I'll call north Praca Fernadez, a square below the University and a wonderful park Jardin de Cordoaria just a little further down. Go see all and you will be across from the Clerigos Tower and church.
Wonderful area. Because it was Saturday there were vendors filling up 2 of the squares. which made for a wonderful day.
reviews/3/text:
The interior of the church is an excellent example of the Portuguese baroque.  Descriptions and photos do not do it justice.  The scale is relatively small, giving the church a gem-box quality all of it own.

Few of the TripAdvisor reviews capture the beauty of the tile work on the side of the churches, so I will include a couple to whet your appetite.
reviews/4/text:
When standing in front you'd think you're looking at a single Church.
However, there're two of them - one by another, a very unusual site.
Igreja dos Carmelitas is the left one, little bit smaller, but more lavishly decorated in Baroque and Rococo.
Entrance is free, and for a small fee you can tour both Churches as well the "Hidden house" between them.
reviews/4/title: The left one of the twin Churches
reviews/5/text: The Igreja dos Carmelitas Descalços (Church of the Carmelites) is located right next to the Igreja do Carmo (Church of Our Lady of Carmo), so be sure to visit both. It is a national monument. Inside the church you can enjoy the gilded carvings, beautiful decorations and the chapels. There is also a museum you can visit.
reviews/6/text: Very lavish and beautiful, however, I don’t like it when I can’t light a real candle in a church for remembrance. Worth a visit, for some spiritual healing
reviews/7/text: How unusual to see two churches on the same city block! Igreja dos Carmelitas is on the left, the Igreja do Carmo on the right, and separating the two – a tiny little house, the Casa Escondida (the hidden house). It’s hard to detect even when you know it’s there! The Carmelite church, part of a now defunct convent, was built in the mid-17th century. Free entrance to see the incredibly lavish, gilded apse and side chapels built in the Baroque and Rococo style.
reviews/8/text:
A charming city with very beautiful views. The Portuguese citizens are very kind, love to help.
The city is very clean.
The city now has renovations in central locations, and that has hurt our enjoyment a bit, which is a shame.
reviews/8/title: A charming city with very beautiful views
reviews/9/text: A large church, which is one of the most important cultural monuments in the Port. A place where you can start your acquaintance with the culture of Portugal. Inside it is very beautiful, neat, spiritual, and calm. Definitely recommended visiting.
reviews/9/title: A piece of significant Portuguese heritage
reviews/10/text: Big church just in the center of the city and a "must" if your visit. Amazing typical protuguese architecture and decoration.
reviews/11/text: Located in downtown Porto, the Carmo and Carmelitas churches  look like one big church.  In fact, they are two churches separated by one of the world’s narrowest houses. If you look closely, you’ll find Carmo Church ,on the right, and Carmelitas Church ,on the left. Beautiful church like many others in the beautiful city of Porto. Construction began in 1616 and was completed in 1628. This church attracts attention with its baroque interior. The interior decoration was completed only in 1650. The admission to the church is free.
reviews/11/title: A gem in the city of Porto
reviews/12/text:
The interior is absolutely stunning!

Even though I must admit I came in the area for a picture of the side covered in azulejos of the church next by, I was impressed of how the interior of Igreja dos Carmelitas looks like.

The pictures I believe speak for themselves.

Also if you are in the are, make sure you take a picture of the tram with the two churches in the background (I forgot to do it :( ) and also don’t miss Lello Library which is very close by.
reviews/13/text:
Looking at them from the front, this is the church on the left.
It does not happen every day to see two churches divided only by the priest's apartment.
reviews/14/text: In this church you literally hot bling because of amount of gold pattern everywhere. You could say that all churches in Portugal are with such decor, but this is a whole new level.
reviews/15/text: The altars of the church are covered in gold and very majestic! It is really impressive and worth a visit. It can be touristic though.
reviews/16/text:
What looks like one enormous church is actually two separate buildings. Igreja do Carmo and Igreja dos Carmelitas are both extravagant sights to behold. Admission to the churches are free. Igreja dos Carmelitas is on the left and  Igreja do Carmo is the one on the right as you face them. Igreja dos Carmelitas is NOT the one with the blue and white tiled side wall (azulejo) . Many people here a making a review for the wrong church!! Look very carefully between the two church, in the middle there is a house that’s separates the two churches, no more than a meter wide. It’s known as the hidden house. The house is so thin, it’s easy to mistake it for a wall. It was even inhabited up until the 1980's. Now, visitors can buy a ticket to peek inside this unusual building. For a nominal fee you can visit the the narrow house, the churches small catacombs, go to the portal behind the statue of Christ (in the igreja do carmo) so you could kiss his foot, see a mummified woman, etc.
It is worth your time to stop, and visit the 3 attractions (Igreja do Carmo, Igreja dos Carmelitas and the hidden house between the two!
reviews/17/text: The outside tile work on this Church is a beautiful sight. We walked around to a couple locations to see it from various angles. The inside of the church is also pretty spectacular. Certainly worth a visit when you are in Porto.
reviews/18/text: After visiting the bookshop, make your way up to the Carmo square from where you get the best views of this church.  An impressive exterior and beautifully decorated interior.  The street car will also bring you up here.
reviews/19/text:
The church is beautiful, it was built in 1616 and it is now a National Monument.
Deserves some pictures if you pass by.

description: WORLD OF DISCOVERIES is, from April this year, a must-see to fully understand the country's extraordinary history. An Interactive exhibition that recreates the fantastic odyssey of the Portuguese navigators, crossing oceans to discover an unknown world. Get onboard of a caravel and prepare to discover new worlds, flavors and people in a total area of 5000 square meters. Some of the technological features as 4D Globes and Fog Screens are completely unprecedented in the country and open doors to an entirely new and fantastic time when setting off to the sea was the most adventurous thing one could do, the equivalent of today's space travelling.

reviews/0/text: I came across this sight. It looked interesting. It was indeed, or much better than I thought. After a brief introduction, I entered a boat and "sailed" across the country's history of navigation and discovery.
reviews/1/text: A kids-friendly attraction that nearly everyone will learn something new. The theming is great. The boat ride was my best bit of the trip. However my advice for the museum is to introduce more about the most common diseases and injures whilst discovering.
reviews/2/text: The interactive exhibits are good. The boat ride is not that exciting although the displays are put together well. However, the story told is a completely uncritical colonialist perspective in which the brave Portuguese and other Europeans brought nothing but good to the world, and “discovered” many places that had never been seen before, except of course by the people who were living there already. There is no mention of the dislocation or suffering that invasion and conquest brought. This is not really history, it is propaganda. Very disappointing. Avoid.
reviews/3/text: Museum was great, really enjoyed it and well worth it. We ate at the restaurant afterwards and were bitterly disappointed.  Confusing menu (and we speak Portuguese!), poor service (slow and a bit rude), and wanted to charge €7.50 for some bread and tuna they serve without informing you that it's charged separately. Highly recommend eating elsewhere.
reviews/4/text: Went in with 4,5 and 7 year olds. They genuinely loved the experience and in fairness so did I. It wasn’t too busy and the boat ride was a nice surprise. An excellent way of learning some Portuguese history. Highly recommend.
reviews/5/text:
We had read some of these reviews but still decided to do it given it was pouring rain and really didn’t have other options. 

That said, for 12+ and only 45 min it was quite disappointing. Sure, there was some history and the boat ride was neat, but the time/experience/value was not on par compared to other museums, food, tastings, etc (including in Lisbon!). 

If In Lisbon check out the science museum (Pavilhão do Conhecimento - Ciência Viva) - that is TOTALLY worth it. For €9 you get a ton more interactive exhibits and can spend 2+ hours.
reviews/5/title: Not worth the price of admission
reviews/6/text:
The museum is probably best suited for a younger generation, however, we as a retired couple thoroughly enjoyed our time, as we learned  a bit of portuguese history while having fun at the same time! 
The kids will really the cute little boat ride at the end!
reviews/7/text:
The museum isn’t too near to the middle of Porto, though don’t let that put you off as it’s well worth a visit.
There are lots of exhibits, & plenty of chances to press buttons, as well as the boat tour at the end of the visit.
I learnt several things about Portugal & Porto I would not have known otherwise.
I didn’t visit with my children, though am sure they would have enjoyed themselves as much as I did!
reviews/8/text: I wish I had this interesting way of learning about the history of the Portuguese discoveries when I was in school 40 years ago! Better spend 1-2 hours inside as there is much information and the boat ride takes 20 minutes. There was no queue, so we could quietly enjoy the exhibitions. Some buttons on the exhibition displays were not working and the sound in the boat should be improved, as it is sometimes difficult to hear the recorded narrator. The entrance fee is also high. Overall we recommend the World of Discoveries to everyone.
reviews/8/title: Interesting way to learn some Portuguese History
reviews/9/text: Been there with 2 teenagers and one 2y old babe. I do t expect Mutch and I was very surprise how good was, clean, well organise, very I tereactive
reviews/10/text: This is quite expensive, 2 adults and 1 child for 30 euros, which they say includes a discount. There are 4 rooms to visit, they explain or show the age of discoveries, the interior of a ship and what if carried and a shipyard. They are ok, but more interactivity like playing games would help beyond the touch screens which just provide info. The boat ride is the key part, it is arranged nicely, but as you watch and listen you wonder if really those nations would not have been better off (Portuguese built mines, gave them guns and ammo and others not mentioned here). Nice, but definetely overpriced for us.
reviews/10/title: More interactivity required at this price
reviews/11/text: Interesting displays that you could actually touch!  Good for both adults and children with many interesting facts and realistic exhibits. Enjoyed the boat trip at the end which illustrated the extent of Portugeuse exploration and had very well thought our displays. Well worth a visit.
reviews/11/title: Better than It Looked from the Outside!
reviews/12/text: It was fun and easy going.. Boat trip was imaginative and brought the rest of the display together. A good wet weather venue...
reviews/12/title: Interesting and more suited to Children
reviews/13/text: A good place to refresh your history of the Portuguese discoveries. You finish your visit with a boat trip through the jungle. Also try the restaurant, the francesinha is delicious.
reviews/14/text: My husband wanted to go into this place and I was very reluctant but was surprised at how much I actually learnt. The first section is all interactive and teaches you about life on a ship and various famous Portuguese explorers. I knew nothing about Portuguese history so this was a good experience and explained how a lot of Portuguese products and culture had come about. The place was pretty empty with a few kids who were really enjoying it and one family said this was their second trip in two days. The second part is a riverboat type ride with different sections about Portuguese travels around the world. It was mostly aimed at children but I actually had a great time - although wasn't overly happy about the stuffed animals. Again very informative and once you depart you enter a very well stocked gift shop. I thought that this whole experience was really modern and there isn't really anything else like it that I saw in Porto. The price is fairly is fairly steep at around €24 for an adult ticket but the amount of investment that has gone into the attraction makes this price understandable.  A great one to keep kids (and husbands) entertained for a couple of hours.
reviews/15/text: I don't often leave Trip Advisor reviews but felt compelled to do so in this instance to hopefully save some poor souls wasting €36 like we did! We came here on the recommendation of a childless friend as a group of 4 adults, a 4 year old, 2 year old and a baby. We spent about 10 minutes looking through the initial rooms where the majority of exhibits were extensive written paragraphs- useless if you're 4 or 2 and can't read! The kids briefly admired the lifesize plastic rhino (honestly very little else for small kids, I'm genuinely confused as to how they settled on €14 being the right entry price for this) then suddenly we found ourselves at the VERY long, very narrow queue for the boat ride which we couldn't fit the buggy into. Cue 4 year old sobbing hysterically because of the creepy moving mannequins stationed in this room and baby crying because she was fed up of the queueing in the dark. Needless to say we were forced to skip the boat ride and won't be returning. I suggest you give it a miss if you have small children.
reviews/16/text:
One of the best attractions that Porto can offer for children.
Kids will love it, as it is very interactive and fun. I advise you to buy tickets online as it is less expensive. :)
reviews/16/title: Great is visiting Porto with children.
reviews/17/text: Our daughter loved this place. She enjoyed the interactive museum and really enjoyed the boat ride. If our daughter was not with us, I don’t think we would have gone to this museum. This museum is for kids.
reviews/18/text:
This is a great museum/educational centre. The first part you walk through has lots of touch screens with information on old Portuguese sail boats, and equipment, and an interactive digital globe. Then you walk through to a room set out like the inside of a ship with displays of the goods that they discovered and brought back to Portugal. Then you go on a 20 minute slow ride on water through exhibits illustrating the places that the Portuguese discovered. There is a commentary on the boat and there is a lot to see. After the boat the experience is finished and you leave through the gift shop. Our 7 year old daughter loved it all and learned a lot. 
If one were to quickly run through and not spend time in the walk through part then it would be a short experience and not worth the entry fee. We spent one hour here in total, including the gift shop. I expected a cafe but when I asked about it I was told that there was a restaurant on the top floor but it was closed at the time (midweek 10am). Overall, I would recommend for children of school age.
reviews/19/text:
Our visit to this potentially interesting exhibit was totally ruined by the large amount of school groups they let in. No consideration was given to the normal paying public and it was pretty impossible to look at anything with misbehaving children running everywhere. We were even asked to move away from the exhibits a couple of times as they wanted to give talks to the children. At €14 each it's not cheap either especially when you cant get to look at the displays. My advice..
avoid it at all costs unless it is the school holidays!
reviews/19/title: Visit ruined by naughty school children
