reviews/0/text: This 18th century church is very famous with its blue tiles. It reminded me the Baroque churches I saw in Ouro Preto- Brasil. A must see place when visiting Oporto!
reviews/1/text: We didn’t go in, but the facade itself is stunning and well worth a stop of several photos! Close to several other buildings of particular azuljero interest too.
reviews/2/text: We stayed at a hotel near this church. We left the hotel before dark and it looks average. But when we back at night, the church was lit up and looks very beautiful. I could see the details of the tiled walls.
reviews/3/text: We were impressed by the magnificient tiling on the exterior of this very pretty and attractive church on Batalha square  Inside the church is interesting and the museum well presented.  We can throughly recommend a visit if you are in the area.
reviews/4/text:
This Church stands at the southern side of the pedestrian Rua Sta Catarina street, opposite the Chapel of Souls which is on the northern side.
While the Chapel of Souls has more dramatic Azulejos tiles on its facade, it is packed among other buildings there. 
Contrary to it, the Santo Ildefonso stands isolated and little bit elevated which adds to its beauty.
However, it was closed around 2 PM, so we just admired it from a small square in front.
reviews/5/text: This is a quiet church with fewer tourists than others. The actual closing time is about 8:00 p.m., which is long before the Internet suggests at 10:40 p.m., so don’t believe the hours on Google and arrive before it’s too late!
reviews/6/text:
Located nearby Praça da Batalha, stands on top of an adjoining hill
Inside includes a framed altarpiece by the prolific Italian architect, which works can be found over over Porto including the Torre dos Clerigos, Porto Cathedral and the Igreja de Santa Marinha in Vila Nova de Gaia.
The Igreja de Santo Ildefonso stands on a slight incline and has a striking façade of over 11,000 classic blue and white azulejos, depicting the life of Saint Ildefonso and stories from the Gospels. 
The church also has some beautiful stained glass windows and a pipe organ
The two bell towers are topped with stone crosses, masonry spheres and flag poles with flags of Portugal.
reviews/6/title: Impressive tiles and the facade of this church
reviews/7/text: Take some photos outside this large church on the top of a hill.  The outside is impressive.  Inside is a museum of forgettable church pieces that are somewhat cartoonish.  And the interior of the church is tacky also, so just stay outside.
reviews/8/text: We paid to go into the church and museum, but we were told moments later that the museum closed 15 minutes ago. The inside has basic statues and burial shrines.
reviews/9/text: I really like this church from the outside because it was well separated from everything. For me it had a very dark particular style.
reviews/10/text: Beautiful church on a little hill, in front of where Rua de 31 Janeiro begins from Rua de Santa Catarina. The facade is covered with beautiful azulejos. The church looks like needs a bit of restoration. Limited opening times. Worth seeing.
reviews/11/text:
Easy to find in the middle of a square. The square itself leads to the popular Rue Santa Catarina (nice for shopping). 
Yes, another beautiful church in the middle of the old town covered with stunning azulejos. It does look in need of restoration.
Quite lovely and worth seeing if passing by.
reviews/12/text: Just opposite Mercure Hotel within walking distance, on a small hill. Loved the interior. A nice small classy church.
reviews/13/text:
Such a beautiful building.
The colours are spectacular. There are so many beautiful buildings in Porto the photos do not do it justice. It was a cloudy day
reviews/13/title: Stunning building like so many in porto
reviews/14/text: It is a very central church with the particularly of having two towers and the facade covered with tiles representing the story of Santo Idelfonso. It dates back of early 1700s with inside nineteenth century altarpiece made by Nicolau Nasoni, in baroque and rococo style. Worth a visit.
reviews/14/title: Beautiful church on a small hill
reviews/15/text:
Really striking church set at he end of a busy square with a stunning intricate facade and azulejo tiles. I saw it from the open topped bus city tour and it really struck a chord with me so I got off and had a good look.
That was a good call! Its beautiful inside and out and well worth your time in a city with lots to demand your attention.
It is perched atop some stone steps standing guard above its placa, grand and as I said before, intricate, yet it still seems lived in and local, earthy and used rather than haughty and proud.
reviews/16/text: The church stands at the top of a slope and is rather majestic.  The blue azulejo tiles also make it stand out.  However, when we visited the church was closed and looked as if it had been closed for some time.  The exterior also looked rather worn and faded and the church looked rather neglected.
reviews/17/text: This church lies in the centre of Porto.  Nicely decorated with azulejas and also the innerside of the church is beautifull.
reviews/18/text:
Factually when we see a lot of churches in Europe the first thought to appear is how deeper the real influence of Christian institutions was and how seriously people in Portugal and Spain were affected by such an awful phenomenon as Inquisition...
But, fortunately, those times passed and now we have only silent architectural artefacts remind us of those embarrassing forms of fanaticism...
The faith now lives mainly inside us and the very premises like that we visit to stay close to ourselves.
I definitely like this place since early in the morning apart the very opening it is always free from any visitors, some beautiful organ  music is played at some background and there are no any anti-social elements over the porch...
A very good ambience for thinking when you need that from insides :).
reviews/18/title: Small pretty church of a local parish
reviews/19/text: This church is just off Catalina shopping street and set in a small but pretty square with other  lovely buildings. The tram 22 goes past this area alsoand you can get off to see it.

This was by far our favourite of all the churchs we visited in Porto.

Very unassuming from the location and entrance but as soon as you enter the Church WOW it is stunning. Honestly sometimes in life you just have to sit and take it in and this was one of those times they have performed miracles restoring this place to its former glory and they should be very proud, there is a video there you can watch that also documents the restoration and I'd reccomend watching that to see how well they have done.
reviews/2/text:
It's very rare that I write a review about anything in my country, but sometimes I must do it.
This is one of the best kept secrets of the city of Porto, as it is still not in the rank of the most tourist-flooded places.
I ​discovered ​it ​by myself​,​ when watching episode 16, on September 1, 2021, of the TV series Visita Guiada, on RTP (Portuguese television).
Since than, I was ​just ​waiting for my next trip to the city of Porto, to see it.
It did not disappoint my expectations, as this is one of the most beautiful churches I have ever seen, in several countries in the world that I ​already ​visited.
Its construction began in 1416 and it was completed in 1457.
But a year ago​​ it reopened, after an exhaustive restoration which took about 3 years​,​ that returned it all its former splendor.
An explanatory film is shown in an exhibition room inside.
Entrance is through a ​discrete ​door at the end of Largo Primeiro de Novembro, to the left of the GNR quarters.
This church is a reference of the Portuguese Baroque and one of the greatest examples of gilded woodwork in Portugal.
Its beauty is breathtaking and it is a must see in the city of Porto.
Offers of eggs are regularly left next to the main altar, by couples who believe that Santa Clara will do a miracle, preventing it from raining during their wedding ceremony.
To prevent her from forgetting, they put also their names, along with the​ir​ offer.

It seems to be mainly made for kids. I thought it was a bit underwhelming, especially for the adult price we paid, we were finished really quickly unfortunately. That said, they had some turtles I had not seen before.
reviews/8/title: Small and mainly for kids and first-timers.
reviews/9/text: We decided to visit the place before our trip to Porto and did not regret the decision. Not too big, but more then beautiful marine life. Staff is nice and friendly and we spent more then three hours just enjoying the beauty of wild life.
reviews/10/text: We went to see the turtles and had an amazing time doing the VIP experience and meeting Marisa the great turtle and the staff were amazing letting my son feed her.  It's such a well looked after place is really is worth a visit.  Thanks for a lovely day
reviews/11/text: We visited SEA LIFE Porto because it was cold and raining heavily all day. Our daughter enjoyed the aquarium a lot. It's nicely done, but it's quite average for the price you pay for it. No need to go there on a sunny day, unless you or your kids are huge sea life fans. We managed to do the visit in under an hour, without rushing at all. At the end there's a shop, snack bar and indoor playground which is nice for small kids. Easy access by public transport (bus) from downtown Porto.
reviews/11/title: Nice to visit with kids on a rainy day, but not a must
reviews/12/text: Have good location, the space its beauty, but its a little bit poor for the price you pay! It worth the visit, but its not the obligatory place to go.
reviews/12/title: Well done, some good parts, but... average!
reviews/13/text: It's an awesome place to go with a like-minded friend / partner. They have really interesting specimens and most importantly they seem to be very well cared for.
reviews/14/text: This is good place to know more about fish and other dwellers of the ocean. I recommend to visit this place to everybody especially families.
reviews/15/text: I went in today as had some time to kill. For the price of 13.50 euros I thought it was rather overpriced for a small sealife centre. It was ok, nothing mind blowingly amazing. Some good sea creatures but I did it all in under an hour!! The kids may enjoy it more. Staff were good and helpful.
reviews/16/text: Great place for a family visit. Kids love it. The possibility to see and touch some starfish, feed the fishes, is a great experience for them to get in touch with sea life. The small but important attention to the pollution of the sea, is interesting. Will come back again.
reviews/17/text: We went there to explor the sealife of Portugal. We explored it in one hour with raja feeding. The premises and pools were decent, decorated with enterntainment and multimedial screens. I expected something bigger for that price (not for visitors but for animals). I would recommend the visit for parents with children, even for longer visits.
reviews/18/text:
Sea Life is a little out of the way if you’re in Porto city center without transportation, but you can actually get there pretty easily with public transportation — there are buses that stop right in front of it (just put it in Google maps and it will tell you what line to get and where to catch it — it’s €1.95/ticket, adult or child). 

When you get there, it looks a little run down from the outside, but luckily it’s fine on the inside. There are lots of exhibits and various types of sea life to see, and the kids enjoyed the visit very much.
reviews/18/title: Doesn’t look like much from the outside, but worth the visit

address: Rua Formosa, Porto 4000-214 Portugal
description:
This traditional open-air market first opened its doors in 1837, and remains a historic icon and heart of the city of Porto. The restored and stylish Beaux-art style building houses around 80 traditional stalls and family-run businesses over three floors, selling a variety of fresh produce, fish, meat, and wine, alongside newer coffee shops and restaurants. Beyond food, you can also shop for unique souvenirs like perfume and jewelry from a range of local brands. There are even vendors offering services like knife sharpening.

Visit the market along a tapas or walking tour of Porto to learn more about Portuguese street food and culture. – Tripadvisor

reviews/1/text: This market is recently renovated and has great vendors that offers delicacies, flowers, fruits, liquors, coffee, produce and spices.  It is definitely worth a walk through.  An hour is more than enough.
reviews/3/text: Love it! A must see if you're in town! This place is a very clean farmer's market. You'll find a large selection of vendors - florists, fresh fish, fruits, meat,  veggies, wine, cheese, clothing, and many more! reviews/4/text:
Great (mainly under cover) market.
Very clean and lots of variety with very reasonable prices.
We did some Port tasting (and buying!) at the Casta D'ouro (stall B24) and the ladies there were very friendly and welcoming. 
We also bought lots of tinned mackerel from the large stall (numbers 77-78-92-93). They allowed us to taste some before we bought (price factored into your purchase).
Again very friendly stall holders.

We wish we had come into this market before buying from the Comer e Chorar Por Mais shop (on the same street) as the port in the market was considerably cheaper...

Shame we weren't in self catering accommodation because there were some lovely fish/seafood and meat stalls, as well as some fabulous vegetable and fruit stalls.

Lots of cafe/snack stalls so you could eat + drink there too.
reviews/5/text: Fun suprise find in Porto!  Many interesting vendors where you can stroll, browse, sip wine and enjoy meeting the vendors.  Really clean space and welcoming.  Will return!
reviews/6/text:

I called the phone operator and she said no disability card you have to follow the rules .

reviews/7/text: This is a covered market in what looks like a newly renovated old building. The produce stalls seem high quality such as fruit, cheese, olive oil etc. really worth a walk around. If anyone knows Borough Market in London then this is along the same lines.
reviews/8/text: We found this market to be an extremely clean and pleasant market offering a wide choice of goods for both locals and visitors. We were particularly taken by the large range of canned sardines and pates available and in fact purchased a number to bring home.   The top quality produce was well packaged and presented making suitable welcome gifts to take back home.   It is also a good place to stop by for a glass of wine and to sample the food on offer.  Prices were reasonable for the quality of the merchandise.
reviews/9/text: Lovely clean market. Food looked excellent and fruit juices were very good. Looks as though it is well looked after and great variety of food, seafood etc.
reviews/10/text:
Wonderful experience  
Excellent seafood 
Friendly folks ,people are ready to help you buy train tickets.  If your battery suddenly dies,helpful folks are ready to lend their chargers. 
In restaurant they help you with the menu by blending their mobiles to see the english menu.
reviews/10/title: Definitely I will return to relive my wonderful memories
reviews/11/text: Nice well-kept market in central Porto.  Most interesting to see all the fresh fish and the locals buying it.  The rest is nice but a bit touristy.  Worth a quick visit.
reviews/12/text: This is a typical Portuguese market that is located a bit far from the historic centre. However we decided to pay it attention. It takes a good 15 min to get there by foot from Sao Bento with photo stops. The market inside is like any other market with stalls offering fruits, vets, cheese, honey, meat. There are a few coffee shops where you can get a sandwich and a coffee or a glass of wine. It is covered market, so it is worth it on a rainy day and it is raining quite often in Porto. So, good to start exploring the city from there and slowly moving to the historical centre.
reviews/12/title: Very lively place with option to taste wine and food
reviews/13/text:
Newly renovated, fresh market.
Lively and vibrant on a Saturday. Lots of fresh produce, local food. Wine and Port available to buy by the glass.
A lovely way to spend a couple of hours
reviews/14/text: The Bolhao Market is a MUST if you are visiting Porto. It is vibrant, well laid out, great spot to pick up LOCAL produce, sauces, etc. The vendors are so friendly, knowledgeable and full of info. We had great interactions and conversations with multiple vendors and we met a nice mix of newer vendors as well as the 'old guard'. Visit Bolhao for a true figurative and literal taste of Porto.
reviews/15/text: The Mercado has only just reopened after a refurb.  It is immaculately clean and well organised. Open all day. And every stall is a feast for the eyes. Fruit, vegetables, cheese, speciality mushrooms, all manner of salt cod.  There are also stalks selling wine and port by the glass ( the white port was a particular treat) and also a stall selling platters of thinly sliced cured meats.  Combine the wine and the snacks with a nice seating/perching area at one end and you have the perfect snacks.
reviews/15/title: A delight for all the senses
reviews/16/text: Got ripped off first stall in on the left, veggie stall. Gave her 10euro, gave me back change for a 5eu. Then was nasty when I pointed it out. Gives the whole market a bad reputation. All others were patient, kind and friendly. Shame on her.

description:
The Serralves Foundation is a cultural institution with a contemporary vision of Art and Landscape, being considered one of the cultural institutions of reference in Portugal and the most relevant in the north of the country.

The Foundation’s landscape and architectural heritage consists of the Museum of Contemporary Art, the Serralves Villa (a unique example of Art Deco architecture), the Casa do Cinema Manoel de Oliveira (Cinema House) and the 18-hectare Serralves Park which is complemented by the pioneering Treetop Walk: an elevated walkway close to the treetops.

reviews/0/text: I loved this museum and the surrounding grounds! We had a lovely buffet lunch with wine on the roof deck of the restaurant and then spent the rest of the day exploring the grounds and museums. The art deco villa is fascinating and we were fortunate to see an amazing Joan Miro exhibit. Everything was beautifully presented and we really enjoyed our visit. Nice gift shop too!
reviews/0/title: Lovely Museum and Art Deco Villa
reviews/1/text: Spent a lovely afternoon at the Museu Serralves. Everything about the museum and the gardens was wonderful. There is a tree walk in the gardens that provides a nice view from the tree tops. The cinema building was a marvelous little gem! Fun to discover new directors and their creative works. The pink house  - Casa Serralves, holds a large collection of Miro. The house itself is an art deco marvel. Fascinating architecture and interior details, and beautiful formal gardens out the front, melding into the larger gardens surrounding the museum complex. The museum itself housed an interesting collection of works from Portuguese artists. One of the artists created immersive rooms that were really creative. Well worth spending your afternoon here!
reviews/2/text: Park is really pretty. We were there in the evening so there weren't mamy people in. Fortunately because of that we could see everything very clear and close. Tree top walk is amazing. Though it's not really high you can sit there on a terrace and just listen to these tens or hundreds of birds singing so untipically and loudly. I think it's a perfect place to take some rest. Also if you're there don't forget to take a picture in front of its Modern art museum.
reviews/3/text:
There are three things that make this place a must see visit..firstly the buildings design is exceptional, think of the Getty or Bilbao Museum - it is remarkable. Secondly the Art Deco House in the grounds is one of the best Art Deco Houses in Europe and worth a visit alone and finally the gardens - with their tree top walks, paths to the river and sculptures are a perfect place families.

The Art collection is quite good too...it really is worth the visit
reviews/3/title: Exceptional Museum and one of the best places in Porto
reviews/4/text: Very expensive for what you get. Grounds are beautiful and the museum is very modern art, some of it interesting, some of it makes you shake your head. It’s not very big and many parts are under construction. Less art than you would expect. The tree top walk is nice for smaller children. But again the price and distance from central Porto is a deterrent.
reviews/5/text: We read the reviews and so knew it was not necessarily going to be the most amazing art exhibition. We chose the garden with the tree top walk which is now included in the price. We were very disappointed. Hardly any sculptures and although a pretty enough garden and art deco building it was not worth the 12euros. The treetops walk seemed pointless. To make things worse we were not shown the ticket price list at the ticket office so missed out on the discount for the over 66yrs. When I asked about this after buying the tickets I got a shrug of the shoulders. Basically we thought it was vastly over priced. We had a much better and free garden experience in Coimbra at the Botanical Gardens.
reviews/6/text:

“Barbershop “ exposition was, in my opinion, just laughable: They seem to have put together each and every scrap of paper the guy ever touched, or doodled on, or tried some old pen.

reviews/6/title: Ok if you have nothing else to do
reviews/7/text: Don't charge €20, the gardens OK, museum was complete waste of money,  typical tourist rip off attractions 😢💸😔
reviews/8/text: So bad, don’t waste your time. Worst museum I’ve been too. Wouldn’t go if it was free. Barely any art, poorly presented. Unimpressive gardens.
reviews/9/text: Lovely maintained and varied gardens with several distinct areas with stunning architecture and sculptures throughout
reviews/9/title: Beautiful parkland and cool Art Deco home
reviews/10/text: The gardens are nice I guess but the museum is really small and abstract, I liked or understood almost nothing. The outside is ok to take a stroll but also nothing spectacular. Maybe worth it if youre a student as you get - 50% but absolutely not worth the full price.

reviews/11/text: Go for the garden, not the museum. The garden is massive, beautiful and great for a nice walk or picnic. The treetop walk is also great for pictures and the view. The exhibition/museum itself is quite sad and uninspired.
reviews/11/title: Great garden with a small museum on the side
reviews/12/text: Very nice Museum but too expensive for such a small collection. This lousy customer service really needs to be improved , especially in these challenging times.
reviews/12/title: Nice Museum, Rude Coat Check Person
reviews/13/text: The museum’s building is modern and nice to walk around. We went to see Joana Vasconcelos collection which was very interesting. The gardens, containing some art pieces as well, were wonderful. Definitely recommend!
reviews/14/text: When I saw the price (20€), I decided that I am so not going in and I am happy for that. The surrounding park is so breathtaking and photogenic I switched like 2 film reels on my camera when capturing it. Casa de Serralves is so pretty and gardens in front of it aswell. Also, you can find (near museum) an olive tree which was 1501 years old by the time we saw it. So awesome! One point down for price of the museum (really wanted to go in but didn’t want to waste that much money without even knowing if it’s worth it).
reviews/14/title: Just skip the museum and enjoy the gardens around.
reviews/15/text: A great museum for contemporary art, if you’re into that. Features a beautiful park with an Art Deco villa and other buildings. It’s a must if you’re looking for a break from the bustling old town Porto has. Also check out the tea house beside the tennis court in the park.
reviews/16/text: A beautiful park with a wonderful Art Deco house in the grounds. Some interesting art in the house and the grounds. Easy to get to on public transport well worth a visit
reviews/16/title: Well worth a visit and easy to get to
reviews/17/text:
Not what I expected, but fascinating. This is not a place to go if you're looking for a permanent exhibit of Picassos, Cezzanes, and Matisses. Instead I saw a beautifully done exhibition of the architecture of Alvaro Siza, Portugal's Frank Lloyd Wright. He designed this museum. It contained amazing wood models of many of his projects, some completed, others never built. If you appreciate modern architecture,this is a must-see.

Then, I went to the other main exhibit hall to see the collage-ish work of Pedro Cabrita Reis -- Cabita. Cool stuff.

Unfortunately, I didn't have time to walk the park. The museum is also a research facility for students, who were working away in a striking -- shhh! -- space.
reviews/18/text: There is a museum with some galleries and a very nice big garden. Actually I didn't get connected with modern are museum, wasn't my type at all and didn't like it but the garden is super beautiful. The garden has different part which can be easily found through the map. There is also a buffet restaurant which has high quality and worth the try.
reviews/19/text: On a hot but breezy day in August, the Museu Serralves was a lovely way to spend the morning and early afternoon. The main museum was interesting but not mindblowing, but walking around the grounds to the home and farm were really the highlights. It was really enjoyable to explore the grounds - there's lots of art and nature to enjoy - and it was a nice break from city streets.  We even got to enjoy some time hanging with a cow who took an interest in us. The home was sporting an installation of significant works from different decades that the Museu had previously featured. They were spread throughout the home in rather anachronistic ways, but did not detract from the house itself. I can see why the poor reviews of this site are from rainy days - this is not a large  collection housed in a massive indoor space - to fully enjoy what the Serralves has to offer, one needs to be happy walking the property as well. Rain would diminish this trip considerably.
reviews/19/title: On a gorgeous day, this sanctuary is a treat.

reviews/0/text: We enjoyed visiting the impressive Bishop’s Palace next door to the Cathedral. There is some stunning art work and the building itself is quite a land mark in this cathedral city. The bishops certainly lived in style back in the day!
reviews/1/text: Really enjoyed this place. Wasn't as crowded as Cathedral next door. Very grand, especially the throne room and the dining room - the place settings were quite impressive. This place isn't the best tourist attraction in Porto but it's totally worth a quick 45 minute visit. Also, after visiting it, you'll notice this Palace in the background of many of the great views you get from Vila Nova de Gaia and some Miradouros in Porto.

reviews/2/text: This is a huge palace with great splendor for the bishop of Porto.  Only allowed to view the staircase and a few ceremonial rooms without any explanation of the use of the space or reason for such a large palace.  Not worth visiting.  Go walk the city and a see how people live.
reviews/3/text: This is a major building on one of the big squares and we walked past it many times during our stay here.  It is very grand and classic Portuguese architecture.
reviews/4/text:
I enjoyed a lot of the splendor of the natural scenes and archaeological sites there.
It was a very enjoyable trip.
reviews/5/text: Palace where Porto church workers used to live and still live (we have seen pastors during excursion). Beautiful palace with nice paintings and items of church workers.
reviews/6/text:
The attraction is the former residence of the bishops of Porto. 
The palace is located on a high elevation, near Porto Cathedral. The architecture is nice and the view is very beautiful!
reviews/6/title: Good attraction in Porto with beautiful views
reviews/7/text: There is a 5€ combined ticket for the cathedral and palace but is not advertised in the cathedral. The staircase is the mist interesting feature. It shows the extravagance the bishops lived in.
reviews/8/text: The weather was appalling when we visited the cathedral a stone's throw from our rental, so paid the extra to visit the Bishop's Palace & so glad we did.  We were the only visitors, so had the place to ourselves.  Stunning rooms & main staircase......
reviews/9/text:
Just next door to the Cathedral.
Ornate rooms housing various decorative items. Former residence of bishops.
reviews/10/text: It appears most people pay the 2-3 Euros to see the cathedral and cloister but don't pay the additional 2 Euros to see this building next to the cathedral which is amazing. This place is stunning. Don't miss it... especially if you enjoy taking photos!
reviews/11/text:
The former residence of the bishops of Porto is built in a late baroque and rococo style and is believed to be the work of Italian architect Nicolau Nasoni.

Buy the combo ticket with the cathedral. Worth the money and time. Both are visually stunning in their own way. It is inexpensive enough that you can go through as fast as you would like and not feel like you wasted your money.

The architecture and main staircase are beautiful and very Porto. Its historical significance helped put other sites we visited into context. There are nice views of the river, Casa de Ribeira and Vila Nova de Gaia.
reviews/11/title: Went reluctantly, but glad we did
reviews/12/text: Went here as part of the 5 euros joint entrance fee for rhe archbishops palace and the cathedral. Excellent value for money with  very impressive cloister, main staircase and its ceilings. We ascended one of the towers of the cathedral from the top of the cloister. Excellent views, especially of the Dom Luis 1 bridge. The climb up was steep (i counted 85 steps to cloister level on the way down)
reviews/13/text: This is a very easy add on when visiting the cathedral. The entrance is stunning and you are led through some interesting rooms about the history of the palace
reviews/14/text: I do not understand why more people do not visit this interesting site.  It is certainly visible from the other side of the river and is very imposing from that side.  I guess it looks small and unimportant from its entrance.  We bought tickets as a combo from the cathedral and were very pleased that we did.  It has an amazing staircase and you are provided with a small brochure to understand the site.  There are a number of rooms you walk through with some interesting treasures presented in each.  Views of the river are great and I hope in the future more effort is made to make this a must see tourist destination as it has lots of potential.
reviews/15/text: This imposing building was once as the City Hall, It is near the edge of the Douro River and very close to the Ponte  Luis bridge
reviews/16/text: The palace is next to the cathedral, and quite a grand building, at least from the outside. Once inside there is a small circuit one can follow. There is a very imposing staircase, then a few nice rooms, but nothing special either, and nothing as grand as the staircase. However, if you visit, there is a very good view (through a glass) of the river and the ponte dom Louis I bridge. There is obviously a small display of religious artefacts.
reviews/16/title: We visited this palace as it was part of a combined ticket
reviews/17/text:
Wandered onto this place with a great view of the city and river and wanted to visit inside the building but they were closed for lunchtime! 

So do make sure you’ve the opening hours established if you want to visit it plus there’s also walking guided tours that covers this venue as we stumbled on a group doing such!

Lovely view and brickwork all round with a majestic tower.
reviews/18/text: Paco Episcopal dates a long way back to the 12th century. It's right next to the Cathedral, located up on a hill in the city centre. It is a grand building and gives you an idea of the sheer opulence some people have been used to living. It is a palace indeed and looks like one too. The most striking feature would be the staircase and the ceiling but there are other areas which are amazing. The architecture is quite lovely. Outside there is plenty of open space and there is a large square, shared, I would think, with the Cathedral. The views from here are literally breathtaking. It's worth walking all the way up the hill, as we did, otherwise you might splash out on a taxi or some other way!
reviews/19/text: We knew very little about the palace, but it was a very good decision to visit it. The stairway is spectacular, so are the beautifully decorated rooms. From one of the back windows you have the most spectacular view of the bridge and Duro river!
reviews/19/title: Take the time to visit it!

Perfect place to sit by the ocean. We didn’t swim, quite rocky and a bit rough the days we were there but there were people dipping in.
Good food, fab hot Choc our friend said, enjoyed the salads and a nice bottle of wine.  Lovely Choc mousse! Went for sundown dinner too, started outside and then moved inside once it got cooler. 
Busy, staff sweet and helpful. All good.
reviews/1/title: Lovely place to sit by the ocean anytime of day, nice food
reviews/2/text: One of the big beaches out at the ocean.  We walked along here and enjoyed the views of the sea.  Reports were that the water was cold, so I am not sure if this is a good place to swim.
reviews/3/text:
This Trip Advisor entry is technically for the beach of Praia da Luz, but most people post reviews of the bar and restaurant of the same name which has a commanding position overlooking the beach. We utilised both so I will comment on both.
The bar / restaurant is reached from a tree lined path from the road above. It has an internal restaurant section but the best spots are the tables under umbrellas fronting the beach. We cannot comment on the food as we only used it as a bar for coffees mid morning and then something stronger in the afternoon. The service levels did tend to suffer when it got busy but as long as you have a table fronting the sea with its superb views of the setting sun, then you can put up with this.
As for the beach it’s a nice stretch of sand but like all the beaches here is quite rocky and faces out to the Atlantic, which tends to be quite wavy, even on a fairly flat day, so it’s not ideal for swimming. There are no beach facilities so bring your own towels to sit on and umbrellas for shade, as you have to get here quite early to beat the locals who tend to sit by the few rocks that do afford shade.
reviews/3/title: Beach with a bar restaurant of the same name.
reviews/4/text: Had lunch with a friend visiting us fro UK. We sat inside on a gorgeous sunny day watching the sea and eating delicious food. The service was great and the whole experience was lovely. Will definitely return.
reviews/5/text:
First visit ever and unfortunately we had a little more than one hour before sunset enjoying our Campari Orange (two) and a quick bite of something small. 

Friendly service and quick bill cancelation.

Comfortable seating and great sea view!!!

Any time again.
reviews/6/text: Sitting up on the deck in the restaurant while eating some gnocchi and watching the sunset is a must when visiting Porto. The food here was delicious!
reviews/7/text: best experience in december! sun, sangria, beer wow waht a relaxing day deff should go there again. i ll be back during the summer for sure
reviews/8/text: Very bad experience. A small bottle of water cost 2.30€. the place is very dirty and I really didn't like anything there
reviews/9/text: Great location and views.  The staff were very friendly but very hard to get their attention.  Every time we needed to order food and drinks I had to get up and go to the bar. Food is also really good.
reviews/10/text:
first we had dinner on the terrace at the beach. the food was traditional and delicious. friendly and fast service. it is a nice beach club with good music. the chairs and tables are simple, the umbrellas blocked a bit the view but we then removed it ;)
second time, we had dinner on the first floor (inside and outside possible) where there is a more exclusive restaurant. delicious food, friendly and polite service giving good recommendations. nice wine list. beautiful view over the atlantic sea. reservation recommended.
reviews/10/title: Beachstyle with more exclusive atmosphere on the first floor
reviews/11/text: Had lunch indoor at this elegant restaurant. The atmosphere was very relaxing and the design just really on point. The pots, the cutlery, everything was of our taste. In two we had the couvert (bread, two types of butter, cream cheese and tomato dip), an appetizer with foie gras on brioche and fig (delicious combination of flavours) and an octopus bean stew. Let me tell you, the taste of each of these dishes was mindblowing. The different ingredients were balanced well and the resulting flavour was really good. For two people the 1-2 persons portion of the octopus was enough, so I would suggest to have an appetizer like the foie gras (again, amazing!) and then a main course. The only comment about the octopus (which was really soft, delicate and great with the beans) is that I would have probably left the chorizo out. We accompained everything with a glass of sangria (we tried both versions, white and red) and it was very refreshing. For finish, we had a Natas do Universo (lemony super fresh mousse) and a Banana e Caramelo V 2.0 (a more rich caramel dessert) and two coffees. Probably we could have skipped the desserts given the price and amount/richness. The service was very good and the bill was for sure pricey (90.40 €) but overall proportionate with the quality of the food, the details at the table and the whole experience here. We got out full and happy. Really amazed by this place.
reviews/12/text: Beautiful beaches, good 4 star hotel, few people which was nice, great weather.  I did a lot of swimming and a couple of visits to nearby Lagos where I did a tour of the caves and coast by boat.  Stunning beaches and coast.  Good for snorkelling.
reviews/12/title: Great Stay in Praia da Luz
reviews/13/text: Lovely tasty food. Lovely service. Reasonable cost. Spacious restaurant with good social distancing Best Indian in Luz
reviews/14/text: Not one of the more scenic beaches in Portugal but very nice boardwalks following along the beach for ling distances. We took the tourist bus to get here. Watched the surfers in January. I am sure in the summer it is a more popular destination.
reviews/15/text:
We started with a mixed drink on the deck. The view was fantastic, the Bloody Mary was awful. A premix with little or no vodka added for $12E. 

The dining room is casual, yet beautiful. The service was prompt and professional. Started with the Grouper Cerviche. It was fantastic. Entres were good, but not great. The seafood de mar was mostly Hake with a lot of empty clam shells, yet the broth was fabulous. Dessert was also very good. 

Expensive, but the view and atmosphere make it all worth while.
reviews/16/text:
If you ever go across the sea to Portugal 
Then maybe at the closing of your day
You will sit and watch the moonrise over Porto
And see the sun go down on Praia da Luz.
reviews/17/text: We walked from the city of Porto and this was the 4th restaurant we walked into and thankfully was open with a view. Service a little slow as very busy but still great service from our waiter. Food ok, no complaints but not amazing. We enjoyed the stop, food, drinks and seting.
reviews/18/text: €6.50 for a pint of super bock. The only smile we got was when the guy was bringing back our change (clearly hoping for a tip). Nice view but dont waste your money.
reviews/18/title: Awful service. Extortionate prices. Uncomfortable seats
reviews/19/text:

Small quantity of free beach furniture 
There are 2 restaurants here
The beach restaurant is high quality fast food
In the main seated restaurant it is a more classy atmosphere 
The fish and shellfish cataplana was absolutely amazing

A brilliant lunchtime

reviews/1/text:
Porto City hall is a neoclassic edifice standing in the very center, at the northern end of a huge square. A big central tower clock dominates it.
Unfortunately, the area is currently under heavy subway construction, so the views and moving around are limited.
reviews/2/text: One of the best places to take a moment and enjoy the atmosphere before walking into the historic area and river. You can take nice photos.
reviews/3/text: Great big building at the top end of Praca Liberdade.  You will definitely see it on our tours about town as it is big and dominates the area.  Very tall as well.  On a very important squre.
reviews/4/text:
Designed by local architect Correia da Silva the Câmara Municipal (City hall) is located at the top of the Avenida dos Aliados, or the Avenue of the Allies, which is a wide avenue in central Porto, home to a lot of interesting building facades.
Originally started in 1920, but not completed until 1957 it consists of six floors and has a bell tower with an imposing clock some 70 meters high.
We did not go inside as we found it when strolling the local area and I am not sure if it is open to the public.
This is a nice section of Porto to walk and explore and there are plenty of other attractions close by such as the Igreja da Santíssima Trindade and  the pedestrianised Rua de Santa Catarina shopping street is a few minutes walk away.
reviews/4/title: Imposing building overlooking a nice open avenue
reviews/5/text: I went here several times to take a picture. In the Christmas season, the building looks more beautiful.
reviews/6/text: Nice place for a walk. The square looks really big after the narrow streets of old town. Many small cafes and bars. Not so many tourists!
reviews/7/text: This building is in one of the best areas of Porto. Architecture is really amazing and the building is well preserved.
reviews/8/text: Camara Municipal do Porto, the city hall, is located in the northern part of Avenida dos Aliados. The current town hall building was built in the years 1920-1957. It was designed by the architect Correia da Silva.  It has over 70-meter tower with a clock. The building was made of granite, and its interior is decorated with a marble finish. Inspired by architecture in the great  palaces of northern France and Flanders. Worth a visit is the beautiful and rich Lost Steps Hall, all in black marble. It is very beautiful building.
reviews/9/text:
Grand & imposing Gothic structure at the top of the big City square. The Palace, Intercontinental is at the bottom end. 
Would be good to go in & see what the view from the top is like.
reviews/10/text: Every city has its hall and Porto is no exception. This is a handsome looking building in a small square near the city centre which predictably has loads of people like me taking pictures. I am not sure whether you can visit. but there may not be much to see inside anyway as it is of course a functional Government building.
reviews/11/text:
The town hall towers over the central square of Porto, Placa Liberdade. Its central tower is 70m high and there is a very popular Porto sign outside that is always swarmed with tourists snapping away. 
I dont know if you can visit the inside, I didnt, but the building is one of the most impressive in the city and is well worth a stop.
reviews/12/text: Although you cant visit the city hall it has an imposing location looking at  historic Porto. Beautiful architecture like most of the buildings around the square. Of note lots of police on every block so it feels safe.
reviews/13/text:
The building itself was beautiful from the outside but we did not go in.

The reason to walk here is to take your photo in front of the large Porto sign. Be aware there is a long unofficial line to take your photo in front of it so be prepared to wait. Great photo!

If you like my review, I hope you'll click the 'helpful' button; those of us who write reviews live for those and it motivates us to do more.
reviews/13/title: Go to take pictures in front of the Porto sign
reviews/14/text: San Bento station is amazing, the staff there are very helpful.  It. Is very easy to travel out, good times and indications of platforms etc.
reviews/15/text: Located about 150 metres from Trindade Metro Station, Porto City Hall Is located at the top of the long Avenida dos Aliados. It is an attractive building with steps leading up to the main door, but tourists are not allowed to wander around inside.  In front of the building is the word Porto, in large blue letters, the colour of the city's main football team.  This location is a very popular spot for tourists' photographs.  How better to show that you have been to Porto than to have your photo taken in front of this?  After viewing the city hall, you can walk down the Avenue which has several statues worth seeing and numerous cafés and restaurants for refreshments.
reviews/15/title: Sits At The Head Of A Long Avenue
reviews/16/text: Fun stop to get your pic on the Porto sign. Be prepared to have a big line and wait your turn...lots of laughter as everyone was getting very creative jumping up on all the letters. It turned into quite a competition to see who could get the coolest poses.
reviews/17/text:
Yes, it's the town hall of Porto.

Magical isn't it? Search for Avenida dos Aliados and you'll find it.

Thank me later!
reviews/18/text: Did not see the inside nice building with a reflective pool in front good for photos as it has a large PORTO in front.
reviews/19/text: I believe that it is a very beautiful and econic building. It is a must photo in front of the word Porto.

description: The Portuguese Centre for Photography (CPF) is a free public service based in Porto, in the building of the former Relação Prison. It was created in 1997 by the then Ministry of Culture and it is currently under the supervision of the Directorate-General for Books, Archives and Libraries. Its competences are aimed at promoting and valuing our photographic heritage, namely through the archival processing of specimens and the management of the National Photography Collection. The CPF also offers an annual programme of temporary exhibitions, a permanent Museum Centre that comprises a rare and valuable collection of photographic cameras, a specialized library - which provides specimen research and reproduction services -, a shop, and free guided tours to the building and the exhibitions upon prior reservation

reviews/2/text: Fantastic, thorough history of photography and photography as far as it relates to Portugal, all for free, in what used to be a prison. reviews/3/text:
We went to Centro Portugues de Fotografia as a recommendation from some friends.
The photos were well presented and it was exciting.
The cameras upstairs were fun to look at, but nothing else.
reviews/3/title: For free and well worth every penny
reviews/4/text: An impressive collection of photography and camera equipment inside a beautiful former jail building. Top tip - the views from the top floor are worth it alone! Also, it's free entry
reviews/4/title: Photography collection in a former jail
reviews/5/text:
It is a pity that an institution with such a huge potential is so badly organized.
The labels (where present) are put so low that I have to kneel down to read them. They should be at the eye's height for an average person.
Also, the English translation is printed in such a thin font that it is barely visible.

reviews/6/text: As a photographer myself I always make a point of visiting photographic exhibitions when I come  across them on my travels. This one was not bad, although large swathes of it seemed to be closed, with very little information in English. The building itself is almost as attractive as the exhibits, and from what I understand used to be a jail.
reviews/6/title: Free entry but not much informaton
reviews/7/text: Fantastic space in a converted old jail is a unique venue for the superbly presented exhibits on the lower floors. The upper floors feature a plethora of cameras through the ages, along with fine views over the city.
reviews/7/title: Unique space with well curated exhibits
reviews/8/text:
I would recommend visiting the center/museum. 
It used to be a jail and now it’s more like a photography museum! And it’s for free! Just in the city center!
reviews/9/text: Free entry for a nice building who present interesting exhibitions, this summer regarding the Hollywood stars.
reviews/10/text:
Honestly, it was a bit underwhelming. We knew the centre was inside of a prison so we expected it to be more..."prisoney" but the truth is that there are very few traces of that. Still, I learnt quite a bit about prisoners such as Camilo Castelo Branco.

Also, I'm a photography fanatic. I loved the exhibitions of cameras and the descriptions near them were very simple and clear. However, I was disappointed with the photos. They were good, but not exciting or inspiring. The selection was not the best in my opinion

So generally speaking, it wasnt a terrible experience but I dont think I'd go back so soon
reviews/11/text:
WOW this was a prison in the 18th century…Cadeia da Relacao!  Amazingly restored and home to Center of Photography.  

The exterior itself, its building structure, layout, steel bar doors and windows, was wonderful! 

They had a very good exhibition and the main stay at the top floor were collections of historic cameras and equipment…from spy to large format cameras. They had the 1888 first Kodak  camera.

Visit to the museum is free😀.
reviews/12/text: As others have noted, a largely empty former prison.  Plenty of interesting spaces if they would just hang some photos.  One exhibit of rock concerts, another one that appeared to address former prisoners (all info in Portuguese) and two other collections with unclear themes.  Maybe a reflection of lack of funds- no admission fee.  Top floor has huge collection of cameras haphazardly displayed.  Pretty much a waste of time.
reviews/13/text:
The museum has a large collection of camera equipment so if you are interested to see this go ahead. Hardly no translations in English. Free entrance.
We thought to discover old photos but nothing.....
The building in itself is intersting because it was a jail. Bu I expected to have more explanations or a guided tour.
reviews/14/text: This attraction was advised by our Porto free walking tours guide - if you have spare hour or even less - the place is worth to visit not only for photography lovers. Former prison building creates a unique atmosphere to photography exhibitions, split into many small rooms. Collection of photo-cameras of all ages and all sorts on the top floor is fantastic and well done. Entrance is free.
reviews/15/text: We discovered this museum of cameras and photography by accident, just scanning the maps app on our device. It is housed in an old prison, which is an imposing yet not typically oppressive building near Clerigos. The photo exhibitions change regularly, but we saw an amazing collection of black and white photos relating to people in various forms of incarceration around the world, with accompanying information in a number of languages. It is heavy stuff, but important to see and read about. The museum of cameras is most impressive, especially if you are a camera buff. And the whole experience is totally free!
reviews/16/text: Probably the most amazing and well-organised photographic exhibition place and museum. To building is magnificent, the spaces well used. The display of at least 200 cameras of every type imaginable is astonishing.
reviews/17/text: This is an old prison that has been converted into a photograph museum. It has a lot of interesting cameras. But the photos were not of my liking. There’s no cost enter so you should enjoy.
reviews/18/text:
An exhibition of photography situated in the site of the cities former old gaol.  A great use of a really atmospheric building.  There are some really poignant images on the ground floor (photos of prisons / regimes around the world).  Some difficult issues, but worth a viewing.  The upper floor has displays of cameras throughout history.  Some really cool stuff.  The exhibition is free...which is great.  The highlight for me personally was the building.  As a former officer having worked in several old victorian jails, I was really interested to view the interior.  I guess if the walls could tell a story.  I have no doubt that it must have been an oppressive place to occupy.  Really enjoyed the visit.  Free entry.

Definitely worth a visit.
reviews/18/title: An atmospheric museum with a former prison.
reviews/19/text:
..... like many other posters here, I was frustrated that a lot of information was only available in Portuguese and I could only guess at 1 word in 10.  I speak reasonable French and a little Spanish but neither help enough with Portuguese!

There were only about 10 other visitors in the building when I was there and I loved the way the building's original purpose remains so obvious.  I found standing in the women's cell an oddly moving experience.

I wanted more information/photographs about the prison AND more about photography.  It felt like all the effort/resources had gone into preserving the building and there wasn't enough left for the contents!  

I liked the (very) small but thought-provoking exhibition of work by two photographers - Edson Chaga's pictures stopped me in my tracks and the eloquence of Lien Botha's Wonderboom made me cry.  

Someone at the museum clearly has good ideas/connections but there is a great opportunity here to do MUCH better.  Maybe keeping the museum free is limiting its development; if you build on it they will come - and pay?

reviews/1/text:
Praca Gomes is a lively and beautiful square around the University of Porto.
From here you can catch the walking guiding tours, enjoy the street performers, cool down in one of many cafes/restaurants of catch the old tram from its starting station.
The middle of the square is adorned by a nice fountain, while one of its corners is dominated by the famous twin Churches - Igreja do Carmo and Igreja dos Carmelitas (see that review).
reviews/2/text: This area was full of students when we arrived as graduation was near.  They came here for their colorful celebrations.  It's a big open square with a big university building on one side and the colorful churches on the other.  We passed through here everyday and it was lovely.
reviews/3/text:
Praia Gomes Teixeira refers to the name of the wide open square, not the name of the fountain. The prominent fountain here is actually called Fonte dos Leoes and is an octagonal Roman-style marble fountain featuring 4 lion statues that was originally built in the 19th century.
We found this square to be a lively place, usually featuring one or two street entertainers and buskers, but also a magnet for the many guided walking tours due to the rectory of the University of Porto and the beautiful church of Carmen ( Igreja do Carmo ) being around the square. And also one of the routes of the historic trams goes past its northern edge.
There are also a good selection of cafes around or close to the square, which takes its name from  a famous Professor at the University of Porto, Francisco Gomes Teixeira.
reviews/3/title: Wide open square with plenty of attractions in and around. Provides good photo opportunities
reviews/4/text: The fountains of Portugal are beautiful!  Stand back and enjoy the piece of art, then look closely at the detail and you will find exceptional detail.  Also, do some research and the inspiration behind each fountain.  Enjoy your trip!
reviews/5/text: Nice aquare just in the center of the city. Take a look if you pass by. The square is very wide and there are a few interesting things to see around.
reviews/6/text: A nice feature. We walked past this fountain almost everyday. The whole square is great; open & surrounded by cafes but the it was quiet during Covid.
reviews/7/text: This is an interesting looking and very Gothic like fountain not far from the famous book store, both of which allegedly inspired the Harry Potter books. Surrounded by mythical looking beasties one could easily imagine this. Worth a look if in the area.
reviews/8/text: It is more interesting for Harry Potter fans as it is supposed to be one of the inspirations for J. K. Rowling. It is also near the Livraria Lello, Igreja dos Carmelitas and Igreja do Carmo.
reviews/9/text:
Very pleasant square that I happened on by accident as I wandered around Porto only to see again later from the open topped bus tour of the city. 
Not a lot going on, it's a quiet enough spot, charming though and worth visiting for the beautiful central fountain with the carved Lions. They are seriously impressive.
reviews/10/text: Nice fountain, but not a lot more to recommend it. If you are passing through to somewhere else, it might be worth a look and a couple of selfies.
reviews/11/text:
This lovely square is actually Praca de Gomes Teixeira.

In the center of the square is the stunning Fountain of the Lions. That is why the square is popularly known as the Square of the Lions.

You can also find the beautiful church Igreja do Carmo next to the square.
reviews/12/text:
This is a relatively small yet highly decorative fountain to be found in a largish square on the city tour walking route.

Similarly co-located with the impressive barroque church et al there's plenty to see in this area and not just the fountain.
reviews/13/text:
After visiting Jardim da Cordoaria, our driver/guide took us to Parça dos Leões. This park derives its name from its centerpiece fountain, depicting winged lions, which hold up the large bowl of the fountain.

Our guide suggested that this project was commissioned by the Municipal Water Authority of Oporto, and that makes sense, given the flowing waters from both above the lions, and from their mouths. Initially, it was to commemorate the water system of the city.

The Parça dos Leões is located inside of a larger park, Praça de Gomes Teixeira, with beautiful gardens.

We spent time studying the lions, and the overall design of the fountain, itself. Besides being lovely, and a work of art, the sound of the falling water had a soothing effect in this urban environment.

We felt that our stop at the Parça dos Leões was well worth our time. I would suggest budgeting about 30 mins for the park, unless one might want to linger, say over a picnic, and there are also many restaurants in the immediate area.
reviews/14/text: As you walk around the city, one to enjoy. On a hot day especially appealing with the water of course. No jumping in though.
reviews/15/text: In a lacklustre walking tour we came across this fountain which stood out from other boring buildings.  In good shape and working.
reviews/16/text: This Fountain is Exquisite, surrounded by beautiful buildings, and you can eat and drink at nearby restaurants.
reviews/17/text: This fountain, gave way to inspiring creates for Harry Potter.  Lovely to walk around, take pictures, have a coffee and meet new friends.
reviews/18/text: Praca dos Leoes is a really lovely public space. We went there or passed by the Square a few times, as our hotel was nearby. The Placa is in a fairly central spot and is surrounded by a number of good looking buildings. There are also two beautiful twin churches just across the road, the Igreja do Carmo and the Igreja dos Carmelitas, which seem to complement each other! The Square has actually been named after the Lions of the lovely fountain in the Square. The major public building in the Square seems to be a part of the University of Porto. The Square does not have many trees and greenery, apart from a few palm trees and just a few plants here and there. There are some shops in the vicinity as well, shops such as cafes and so on. The Square is good for a relaxing stop, particularly around the Fountain. We were lucky during our visit as it was mostly sunny and warm, apart from one day when it became rather wet from a storm which fortunately did not last very long.
reviews/19/text: A very nice chance to meet new people, take great pictures of the fountain and the surrounding buildings. The weather also helps you in order to feel free to walk and have a coffee break at one of the nearby shops!  You can even visit the University of Porto which is also a very interesting building with a unique design.

Sometimes, a visit to an old cemetery can provide an insight into the history of the town or city in which it is located. Such is the case with the Agramonte Cemetery, located in Porto, which proved to be an interesting venue to spend a couple of hours. It also houses one of Portugal’s most important collections of sculptures, including works by Soares dos Reis and Teixeira Lopes.

Agramonte was created in a hurry in 1855, as an appropriate burial site was urgently needed for the victims of a sizeable cholera epidemic. Subsequently, in 1869, the cemetery was restructured and incorporated ‘private’ cemeteries that were run by various Brotherhoods within the city. These fenced areas still exist, enclosing the sections operated by the Orders of Carmo, Trindade and Sao Francisco. These three sections take up a sizeable part of the 12 hectare cemetery.

The Order of Carmo has the largest of the three Brotherhood sections, but it is also the least well-maintained. Whereas most of the cemetery has neatly maintained stone footpaths, the Carmo section has dirt pathways with weeds growing along the edges. Both of the sections run by the Orders of Trindade and Sao Francisco have decorative entrance gates and have neat, tidy footpaths.

Between 1870 and 1874, shortly after the restructuring of the cemetery, the chapel was constructed. It was designed by engineer Gustavo Adolfo Goncalves e Sousa. The chapel was enlarged in 1906 by architect Jose Marques da Silva.  Then, in 1925, the Italian painter Silvestro Silvestri produced the Byzantine-inspired paintings within the chapel.

Another sizeable building within the cemetery is the oval-shaped Municipal Burial Monument. This granite and iron construction has three levels (one being below ground). As each of the repositories is small in size, I am assuming that the building is an ossuary, and that each space contains only the bones of the deceased, re-located some time after an in-ground burial.

A memorial monument in the centre of the cemetery highlights a tragic historical event that occurred on 20th March, 1888. On that night, the Baquet Theatre was completely destroyed by a fire that killed 120 people. The monument to the victims includes pieces from the destroyed theatre.

Whilst the cemetery has areas for the more common in-ground graves, much of the facility is taken up by above-ground buildings – crypts or mausoleums – that house coffins of family members. These structures come in a variety of styles and sizes. Some are sombre granite with columns, whilst others mirror a more local style of building, with red slate roofs and even azulejo tiles. Many feature glass doors (some with with lace curtains) and some have their own stained-glass windows on the rear wall. Each one is built in a style preferred by the respective families, whose loved ones are housed within. It is evident that family members visit many of these vaults on a regular basis, as fresh flowers were placed inside many of them.

Whilst most of the crypts bear family names, the casual observer has no insight into the history of those who lay within. However, for some of the more notable individuals, the cemetery has erected plaques that provide a little historical context. These plaques reveal that those interred within the cemetery include actors, musicians, artists, bankers, wine merchants, mayors, race car drivers, etc. 

In contrast to the large family mausoleums, many of the people interred in the cemetery have a simple and small space, in one of the ossuaries that can be found along the perimeter of the property. Many of these small burial spaces have fresh flowers attached to them, presumably placed there by family members and loved ones. Due to the height of these ossuaries, the cemetery provides step ladders so that the individual spaces can be reached.

An interesting place to visit. To see the majority of the cemetery, you'll need about two hours.

The family graves are mainly old mausoleums and some have fantastic statue and beautiful flowers.  Some graves have description signs of the family and / or the artist of the sculpture. 

A wonderful place for some quiet moments away from the busy tourist places.

We discovered this unique cemetery as we were on the way to Casa da Musica and it is worth seeing for a few minutes to see the design of the mausoleums of old.

There are coffee shops on the street if you get hungry. No entrance fee whatsoever. It was clean and well-maintained. 

Very accessible as it is one of the streets in the rotunda in the city. Buses available too! 

Most locals know this so if you are in the area just ask about this cemetery
reviews/15/text: Happened upon this on way from hotel to city centre. I love a good cemetery and this one has the mini mausoleums and neatly kept avenues that make it so appealing. All a contrast to the tower blocks that make a very modern back drop.  It's certainly worth half an hour looking round. The day we visited was crystal clear blue sky and bright sunshine on the fresh leaves of the trees. Made me very happy to be a visitor rather than a permanent resident!
reviews/16/text: I never visit places like this normally however I accidentally stumbled across this place while exploring the city. I ended up spending a good hour or so here. It's huge in scale and the architecture is absolutely breathtaking. It was a very moving experience for me. So much so that I went back the next day and spent another hour walking around. There was hardly anybody there. I think it's a must visit if it is your first time in Porto.
reviews/17/text: My bf and I came across the cemetery by accident. The cemetery consists of graves of notable people of Porto - those who could afford to be buried there. The place is beautiful, some tombs look really impressive. Worth popping in once you're around.
reviews/18/text: If you've been to Recoleta Cemetery in Buenos Aires, Argentina, you may find this cemetery somewhat underwhelming. Regardless, if you find yourself in the area (close to Casa da Musica), it is worth a visit. It is fairly large and there are countless mausoleums. Some are exceptionally ornate. There is a tranquil nature about the cemetery as it is typically only visited by locals. Rows of shade trees line the pathways and manicured gravesites comingle with some of the larger stone/marble tombs. There is an interesting history relating this cemetery dealing with its construction (mid- 1800's) and the cholera epidemic.
reviews/18/title: It's Not Recoleta Cemetery, But Still Impressive

In the main chapel, attention is drawn to the polychromatic altarpiece
The tower extends upwards through 75 meters of elegance forming rhythmic stages before rising to its crowning glory, the spherical clock house.
But be careful, you have to climb 225 steps, you have to be fit, the queue at the entrance is only for the tower, anyway I recommend going up because the views are extraordinary

reviews/5/text: A wonderfully preserved building of great significance in the heart of the old town - worth a visit for the ambience once you step inside the courtyard. Go there and ponder on Porto's far-reaching history!
reviews/6/text: The customs house was a real surprise. It has the remains of buildings from very different time points in the city's history and the mozaic floor from the Roman era is still in good condition. Very impressive.

reviews/7/text:
This museum is free to those who are over 65 years, not free tor everyone. I would have paid a lot more to walk this historic museum and read and view its huge amount of information. A docent would have been nice, but they work on a shoestring budget. I see that trip advisor offers a personal tour of this museum which might be nice if you want more information.
So, some highlights: The mosaic floors from the actual castle; good use of digital displays to focus on porcelain brought back from Asia; good use of interactive displays of indigenous flora and fauna brought back from Brazil complete with animal sounds. The diorama of the city that uses a red laser light to point out areas of Porto from Henry the Navigator’s days was very informative. It helped my understanding of the various areas of Porto snd how they developed. we had seen what turned out be parts of the original city wall in Batahla near the Funicular. I could go on and on, but I believe you must see this yourself, since each person has different interests. Unfortunately, the entry to this fine museum is currently hidden behind  scaffolding and red and orange netting. All text is provided in Portuguese, English, French and one other language I did not know (Spanish?). Here are their hours as I remember them.  Closed Mondays. Other days open 9:30am to 5:30pm, except for Tuesdays, when they are closed from 1-2pm. They may be closed Sundays too.

reviews/13/title: Birth Place Of Henry The Navigator

reviews/15/title: HERE IS THE HISTORY OF PORTO

You will find the “Misericórdia Museum of Porto” in the historic center of Porto, and this in the “Rua das Flores”, in a building who was used as “the institution's headquarters” and this from the mid-16th century until the year 2013. By visiting the museum you will discover the history of the “Santa Casa da Misericórdia”, its institutional purposes and its art collections.
The museum opened in July 15 of the year 2015. And on the 3th of June in the year 2016, he was distinguished with the Portuguese Museum Award of the year 2016, given by the Associação Portuguesa de Museologia. 
The visit of the museum goes as follows, you have to go first up-stairs and then you are coming down again by passing several rooms with different expositions. Worth a visit, even that the entrée fee is not that cheap.

With several floors and rooms of old paintings and history of Porto’s Misericordia, a religious effort started centuries ago with benefactors donating money for helping the destitute infirmary or those who’s ill but too poor to get medical help. 

Very interesting artefacts in the museum and lots of paintings too! 

Well worth a visit.
reviews/8/text: This museum and church package covers the world of hospitals in the day.  Interesting, but more emphasis on the contributors than what they did to help.  Church worthwhile.
reviews/9/text: Unless you are interested in the welfare of the poor over the centuries, and how the benefactors of Porto sought to aid those in need, this is probably not the museum for you. One of the rules of the Misercordia was that portraits had to be made of each benefactor, which were displayed briefly each year. Consequently, there are a lot of portraits of benefactors in this museum. We had a good look at everything, and spent about an hour altogether, but all agreed at the end we'd been a bit disappointed in the specialised subject matter. There was a surprising display of Olivetti typewriters in the room which had been built for displaying the portraits of benefactors, which took me back to my days learning to touch-type on a Lettera 32 in 1969, a skill which has stood me in good stead over the years. The fact I am mentioning this now rather than the items on display in the museum itself says a lot.....

reviews/12/text: We didn’t like visit to this place , but we like church there. We recommend to visit  this just with tourist guide.
reviews/13/text: This small museum located on rue das Flores traces the history of benevolence and major benefactors of Porto for the past 500 years. You start at the top of the museum and walk your way down - the displays are surprisingly interesting. At the end , you can enter the adjacent Igreja de Misericordia through a side entrance - that's an additional plus. Museum staff can be a little abrupt - it took some harsh words with a supervisor to allow my wife in with a water bottle, needed for a medical reason....
reviews/14/text: The museum is well laid out although religious exhibits and not very big the most stunning sight that we got to view from above was the church and that was stunning. Worth a look.
reviews/15/text: Museum shows you the history of benevolence initially, you take the lift up to the top floor and work your way down to the church.  Thought the church was wonderful and a real hidden gem.  Apart from one other person we were the only people in the museum surprisingly.  Reasonable entrance fee of 5 euros and staff looked after our bags whilst in the museum. A peaceful place to visit.  Museum more geared to adults than children.
reviews/15/title: Worth it just to see the amazing church at the end of the museum tour
reviews/16/text: The museum itself is very interesting and displays a variety of objects thoroughly explained in the accompanying notes. The staff was rather unpleasant though and an agent asked to verify our tickets while we were heading for the Church at the end of our visit, which was a bit weird and uncalled for - since the Church gate is closed and cannot be accessed from the street, but only from the inside of the Museum, guaranteeing one has passed by the ticket office... There is also a modern art exhibition in the central courtyard (a leaflet explaining the objects presented is available, placed on a stall).
reviews/17/text:
I bought tickets to this museum as part of a package of tickets. It is a small space over several floors with some interesting artefacts - particularly the chalice made from donated wedding rings. The visit includes the church attached to it. I’m not convinced children would enjoy this one. Even I got a little bored by it and I love museums, galleries and such like. 

But with a €5 entrance fee I think it is pricey. I do think the larger decorative arts museum ‘Museu Nacional de Soares dos Reis’ is considerably better value for money and 100 times more interesting.
reviews/17/title: Ok but better places to visit
reviews/18/text: Just in the middle of trendy Rua das Flores, you´ll find the baroque façade of this church by Nicolau Nassoni. To enter it, you need to buy a ticket which includes a visit of the beside museum, which has the peculiarity that visits should begin in its upper floor, descending later up to the ground floor. It all belongs to Casa da Misericórdia a traditional charitable institution settled in 1499, of which you can learn a lot of things seeing their exhibition.
reviews/18/title: A good insight into local history
reviews/19/text:
The museum offers insight into the history of Porto and its people. The exhibition is very well structured and it is both in Portuguese and English. The price of the regular ticket is 5€ (student ticket - 2,50€). 
Santa Casa da Misericórdia do Porto is one of the oldest institutions in the city and its History is the history of the city.
