reviews/0/text: We stayed very near here and walked past this area many times.  We also lingered here and took photos of the splendid views of the old town and the river.  This is one of the best view points in town.
reviews/1/text: We rented an apartment very close to here, so we passed this lovely viewpoint many times.  It was often busy with lots of folks thoroughly enjoying the spectacular views of the whole region.  One of the best places to get a perspective on Porto.
reviews/1/title: One of the Best Views in Town
reviews/2/text:
Contrary to the capital, Porto doesn't have so much Miradouros, but this one is just perfect.
It is set some 10 min walking downhill from the famous Clerigos tower and Church. Therefore, no need to climb the tower, pay for it and wait in lines.
Miradouro da Vitoria is a wide plateau and there're no crowds and is of course free.
reviews/2/title: Great view for free and without crowds
reviews/3/text:
Yes this Miradouro is one of the best in Porto for its views and you will not be disappointed by the photo opportunities it provides. And also you will experience some of the fantastic narrow streets of old Porto to find it. But as Miradouro’s go it’s a bit shabby, being just a large concrete platform with no facilities ( bars or cafes) in an area still containing several derelict buildings. I’m sure that will change as the renovation of Old Porto continues but in the meantime for a spot to view the setting sun of an evening 
I would recommend Passeio das Virtudes to the west of the Old Town with its tree shaded green space and bars, restaurants and cafes.
reviews/4/text: The views from way up here on the hill are superb.  People gather here to pause, enjoy, and of course take some photos.  One of the best perspectives on the city and the region.
reviews/5/text:
We reached this stunning viewpoint during part of our free Sandeman Walking Tour of Porto and what a wonderful spot to take in the sweeping views over the rooftops and down towards the river Douro.
We were told by our guide that this formed part of the old Jewish quarter.  While in a dilapidated and uncared-for setting, this only added to the charm.  Fortunately it wasn't crowded during our visit and when we returned later on during our stay it was even less busy.
reviews/6/text:
This place is fantastic; you can wonder about all these narrow streets admiring the wonderful architecture & suddenly you have this amazing view.
This area is being renovated fast & a lot of original features will be gone - sanitizing!
reviews/7/text: It is a bit of  a walk to get here through the city's historic quarter, but luckily for me I was staying nearby anyway. Like the other miradors around the city (and there are many) the views are amazing - get here early for the sunrise or late for the sunset and you won't be disappointed.
reviews/8/text:
Just 7 min walking distance from Igreja do Carmo. This walk itself is a treat which takes you through a small local neighbourhood. When you reach at Miradouro da Vitoria you find a hidden secret of sorts. The views of Porto are great, with a long balcony to find a comfortable spot to see the city, and so it does not get crowded here. The spot itself is not well maintained and neglected, surrounded by dilapidated buildings. Go there for the views only.
Climbing down you reach Mercado Ferreira Borges and then reach the main riverside promenade in 10 min.
reviews/8/title: Loved the panoramic views of the city, not crowded here.
reviews/9/text: Miradouro da Vitoria will offer you one of the best panoramic views of Porto.  A little bit dusty and dirty next to an abandoned building. Great for photos and just looking.
reviews/10/text: A Stunning ‘miradora’ is this! The view/scenery takes you’re breath away as you are higher than most of the roof tops looking over the city, the river, the main iron bridge and port distilleries. There are no facilities - it is a very simple area to stand where the views say it all. A spot to head for, for those most of scenic of photos!
reviews/10/title: You cannot find a better panoramic view of Porto!
reviews/11/text: We stumbled across this when making our way down to the riverbank. The reviews across the city, towards the bridge and over the river are great. I wouldn’t suggest walking up loads of steps to get to it, but if you are already high up then it’s definitely worth going to.
reviews/12/text:
This forms a short stop on the FREE city walking tour (where you pay what you think the tour was worth at the end). and what a good stop it was - you may be able to find it yourself but this was but 1 stopping point in an almost 3 hrs tour.

Great sweeping views to be had here - well worth seeking out.
reviews/13/text: Didn't know this existed and just stumbled on it whilst meandering along the old streets taking a wide walk out to the right of Porto on the way down towards the river.  Its just a piece of land belonging to a very old dilapidated house that would make a fantastic Hotel.  The views of Porto in my opinion are the best available and its all free, you kist have to barge selfie/instagrammers out of the way in order to drink in the sight. Should be higher up the list
reviews/14/text: This is one of many viewing spots around Porto. We stumbled across it by chance, while walking the streets. It's a bit difficult to get to, but with a bit of effort you can access it. The views are really great.
reviews/15/text: There is such a pretty sight from here, but I believe just as the city has done with Virtudes and Jardim do Morro, it could make this place a bit prettier since it is a very visited place
reviews/15/title: Great views, but the spot could be improved
reviews/16/text: This view point was very close to our apartment so we ventured up there one morning with out children (11 & 7) to watch the sunrise and couldn't get to the viewpoint. we did have a nice but slightly restricted view. Maybe it opens later in the day, this was 6.45am
reviews/17/text: Very nice view on Porto and it's not hard to climb on it. Nice view on Douro River and Old Porto. Worth to see.
reviews/18/text: We were ambling through the back streets above our hotel and came across the viewpoint by chance. There was a guided walking tour there so we waited until they moved on and then took some photos.
reviews/19/text:
Worth stopping and admiring the view if you are passing nearby. 
Obviously you need to walk up hill to get up here. Be prepared for a pleasant but hilly walk. Then enjoy the view!

reviews/0/text: When you are waking to the historic centre, unexpectedly you Come across with this beautiful church. I went inside. It was very beautiful and quiet.
reviews/1/text: The church is beautiful! I would recommend it, stopping by! If you’re already out, walking, it’s a nice place to stop and see!
reviews/2/text: The church is beautiful its the cemetery that is fascinating. Elaborate tombs and crypts make for hours of wide eyed wandering.
reviews/3/text: Blue tiled outer facade, situated uphill from the train station, beautiful ornate gold coloured interior carvings, religious iconic statues and images pleasing to the eye. Its cool interior gives relief from the heat outside and its serene quietness allows for reflective meditation.
reviews/4/text: This little church is a bit far away from the center but the visit is worthy. There are some hidden parts that are very surprising. Moreover, there is a very impressive cemetry behind the church.
reviews/5/text: For us The Lapa Church is one of the most imposing churches in the city, right behind Porto Cathedral. It is one of the least visited places by tourists but very close to the Aliados Avenue.
reviews/5/title: One of the most imposing churches in the city.
reviews/6/text: At a safe, kept within this church, lies the heart of Pedro. Known as Pedro the 1st in Brazil and Pedro the 4th in Portugal. He was the emperor of Brazil, Portugal and the Algarve. A very important person in Both Brazil and Portugal. At one point his son pedro the 2nd was emperor of Braizil and his daughter Maria was queen of Portugal! His body is preserved in Brazil at the Ipiranga Park, but his heart lies in a safe located at this very church. The church is beautiful and so is the cemetery that exists next to it! Visit both!
reviews/6/title: PORTUGAL's KING PEDRO THE 4th's or PEDRO THE FIRST from Brazil's  heart is here!
reviews/7/text: Igreja da Lapa besides being a beautiful church has one of the best organs in Portugal ! They frequently have concerts with distinguish organists that are usually very good !
reviews/7/title: A beautiful church ! An amazing good organ!!
reviews/8/text: We enjoyed seeing this church and the cemetery, which is well worth a visit.  I noticed that there are guided tours at certain times, which would be fascinating and provide more information. The church organ is apparently one of the largest in Europe. A large room adjacent to the church is home to portraits of the church's many benefactors - the congregation must have consisted of very wealthy and influential gentlemen and ladies. A visit to the cemetery is an experience in itself, as the family vaults are among the most elaborate and attractive I've ever seen.  Several Portuguese authors are buried here too.
reviews/9/text: An absolutely stunning church in the Lapa district. The church is huge and well worth a visit. The attached graveyard is also amazing and also worth a visit. More like a city of the dead!
reviews/10/text: This is a medium sized (by European standards) sized church in a central location. It is worth a quick look inside if you are in the area any way, but I would not recommend making a special out of the way trek to visit.
reviews/10/title: Interesting to pop in if you are in the area
reviews/11/text:
You should see this lovely big church. There is no "talha dourada", so common in a lot of baroque churchs in Porto, but, instead, it has a beautiful granite work - It also has a portrait room full of pictures of the donors, just next the main hall.
If you go at 12:00, 13:00 or 19:30h, at the beginning of the sunday masses you can have a small taste of the sound of the organ. 
Very well lit and, usually, very well decorated with flowers at Christmas and new year's Eve.
Sometimes there are concerts there. Try and see if there is one when you are in Porto. They are usually free.
reviews/11/title: Late XVIII century church with an extraordinary organ!
reviews/12/text:
They do say that it's not the size that matters and in this case I agree. It's not huge, but it's certainly not tiny but it h
Is beautiful. Well worth a peep.
reviews/13/text: Its an ok church. Not very impressive. If you happen to be in the neighbourhood you can easily peek inside. But I would not walk an extra mile as a mustsee.
reviews/14/text: Beautiful church were the heart of a portuguese king & brazilian emperor is kept, in honour of the city of Porto. WHOW! That is impressive.
reviews/15/text: In neoclassical style and built in honor of Our Lady of Lapa in the 18th Century, this catholic temple brings back fond memories to Portuguese and Brazilian visitors. Within its walls, on a safebox, lies the heart of D. Pedro IV, King of Portugal and first Emperor of Brazil, where he is known as D. Pedro I and was responsible for Brazilian independence in 1822. You won't see the heart - it is very seldomly exposed - but the church, with its beautiful paintings, famous pipe organ and very many altars, is a must see in O Porto. Enjoy!
reviews/15/title: An important part of Portuguese and Brazilian histories
reviews/16/text: Iglesia que da nombre al barrio de Lapa, empezada a construirse en el sigo XVIII, y aquí llace el corazón del Rey Pedro IV.
reviews/17/text: Agradezco que en edificios así, aún pueda uno acceder sin pagar por ello. La encontramos de casualidad de camino al centro, y nos sorprendió tanto su exterior como su precioso altar, y la tenue iluminación.
reviews/18/text:
Al encontrarse algo distante del centro, fuimos el último día y casi al encontrarla por casualidad. 
La recomiendo porque es una maravilla.
reviews/18/title: Creo que es la más importante de Oporto
reviews/19/text: Situada en el barrio de Lapa, preciosa por dentro, con un bonito órgano que se puede escuchar mientras hay misa. Como curiosidad conserva una sepultura con el rey Pedro IV (escultura en la Praça Liberdade), ya que acudía a esta Iglesia para el culto y quiso que su corazón se quedase en la ciudad enterrado en esta Iglesia y el resto del cuerpo en Brasil.

reviews/0/text: The museum of the "Carro Electrico" in Portugal, is located in the city of Porto on the border of the river Douro. The museum itself is not the largest, but it is pleasant to be there and enjoy the history of the exhibits from the history of the "Tram", and how people could enjoy them. There is the ground floor where the wagons are, and then on the first floor the machines that could provide the grid with the necessary electrical power for the proper functioning of their vehicles. To park the car, this is possible in the underground garage of the shopping center, just next to the museum, as a conclusion, small but worth a visit.
reviews/1/text: This is a most enjoyable museum - if you buy a two-day tram ticket, the entry price is discounted to boot. We spent far longer in the museum than we planned, but this was because the lady who works there was a most excellent guide & spent lots of time with us showing us details and explaining interesting facts. The trams are a treat to look at but also it is very interesting to learn how such an enterprise was sustained by early versions of electricity plants and before then, horses and steam. The whole building is also great to look at, looking like a scene out of Fritz Lang's Metropolis with its early electric plant and monstrously big machinery  - well worth the visit for that architectural aspect & industrial heritage alone. We can't emphasise enough - to be able to look at a building like that intact, not having been turned into yet another 'cultural centre' (however worthy) is a treat for anyone interested in modernist & industrial architecture.
reviews/1/title: Great industrial heritage building plus lovely old trams!
reviews/2/text:
Sorry to be leaving a bad review but we were really disappointed.
The museum charges €8 for each of us despite the website saying it's €4. The staff just shrugged and said it was out of date.
It's a lovely space but it doesn't take very long to walk round the museum. Definitely did not feel that we got our money's worth. Maybe more suited to avid tram fans.
reviews/3/text: If you love vintage public transit, this is the place for you.  It is the former electric station, power station, and car barn for the region's streetcar system.  The plaques inside will tell you the history of the system, and there are beautiful examples of the vintage cars.  Don't miss the film of the ride on the current trams.  Fun.
reviews/4/text: Great museum to see an interesting piece of history, a historic tram collection housed inside the power station that used to power them. The collection covers trams of varying design accross a period of time with plenty of information boards around. Upstairs may not be everyones cup of tea but we found it interesting to see and read about the power station and its devopment alongside the growing tram network.
reviews/5/text: Lots of lovely old trams on display really liked it. It is quite small and won’t take long to see everything. Got the tram line 1 and was able to get 30% of admission with tram ticket.
reviews/5/title: Great place if you love vintage transport
reviews/6/text: Very nice part of a tram depo turned into museum. Several tram models in very good shape. The engines part is intimidating and lacking info and interactivity. Good museum!
reviews/7/text:
Crich it is  not but the display of beautiful old preserved vehicles, the era of electric traction, the craftsmanship and coach building of a bygone age are all stunning.

The working trams in Porto are a living museum and this collection paints the whole picture from invention, the power supply and the demise of street tramways worldwide.
reviews/7/title: If you love vintage trams it’s for you.....
reviews/8/text: Not the biggest museum around but it the ticket prices are fair and you learn something about the history of Porto. Definitely recommend even if you aren‘t a huge tram geek.
reviews/9/text:
This is a nice spacious museum set in the old tram shed with about 20 or so trans ranging from two horse drawn buses to much later. They are all in excellent condition. One tram contains a screen which gives a “virtual tram ride” through Porto. 

Upstairs is the machine room filled with gargantuan levers and dials like something out of Frankenstein’s workshop.

It’s small place but was enjoyable for 30 minute or so.
reviews/10/text: But well presented, lots of detail on each car, showing the development of trams in Porto. All housed in the old power generation building. Also worth looking at the power control building for a throwback to electro-mechanical equipment of yesteryear. Great value too....8 euro down to 4 euro if you have a day pass on the trams
reviews/11/text:
This is the museum solely on the Porto trams. If you are interested at least to some extent in the Porto trams, trams/railways in general or the history of Porto, it is worth visiting. Beware that it is not as encompassing as some railway museums in UK or Japan, nor is it too family friendly as those in US. 
Recently remodelled, the exhibition halls were well organised. We found every explanation and instruction in English too, and could easily understand the history of Porto tram system and its rolling stock.
The souvenir shops had some nicely designed items.
If you plan to ride a tram from Carmo to the museum, do not fail to wave to show your intent to ride to the driver. While some people may think Carmo is the origin of the Line 18, it seems to be considered as just one of the stops en route (of a circular route) where trams just pass through unless either you wave or a passenger already on it requests for a stop. 

ポルトの市内電車の歴史に特化した博物館です。総合的な日本の鉄道関連の博物館に比べると見劣りするかもしれませんが、予めそういう場所だと納得したうえであれば十分に入館する価値があります。車両展示はありますが、車内に入ったり触ったりといった子供向けのアトラクションは期待しないほうがいいです。
ポルトガルの同種の博物館に比べ英語の説明が充実しており（ポルトガル語の説明と比べると、直訳ではなく、少し雑な内容になっている場合もありますが）、展示の流れもわかりやすいので、ポルトと市内電車の歴史がすんなり頭に入ってきます。
土産品コーナーには街角の土産物店よりはかなり洗練された市電関連のデザイングッズが売られていました。
なお、市街地Carmoから18番のトラムに乗る場合、必ず手をあげて運転士に意思表示してください。ここは起点ではなく循環系統の途中停留所扱いのようで、車内の乗客が降車の合図をするか、待っている人が乗る旨を知らせない限り通過します。そして、往々にして中の乗客は博物館から通しで乗っている（また元の方向に戻る）観光客ばかりだったりします。
reviews/11/title: Worth if you are interested at least to some extent in ...
reviews/12/text: Decided to visit the tram museum on my last morning in Porto as it was right next door to my hotel. If you keep your ticket you get when you ride on the tram the museum gives you a 30% discount on the entry price which in my opinion is just as well because the normal price of 8 euros I think is very high for what the museum offers. In the first section there are some well preserved tram carriages, with information boards that explain their individual histories. The second section upstairs is a collection of engines and electric generators of varying ages, which I did not find very interesting. And that’s it! I was expecting more and after 20 minutes I had seen everything.
reviews/13/text: A brief introduction to Porto and its trams.  There is an interesting timeline right inside the entrance, in Portuguese and English.  All trams were electrified by 1915.  There are examples of public transport from the earliest to the present.  A quick visit, 30 minutes, and I continued my walk along the waterfront.  The upper level was quite boring and of little interest.  Families with children seemed to enjoy it most.  Seniors get a discount, as does anyone showing their tram ticket.
reviews/14/text:
Top tip, if you have ridden on the trams keep your ticket and ti saves you 40% on entry into the museum

Located in a former Power station that supplied the tram network, one hall has a selection of Trams that used to used on the network, the second hall still contains the alternators, rectifiers  and switch gear used to control the electricity

As an Engineer I really enjoyed and hour spent here and for the discounted price of €5, I thought it was pretty good value

The adjacent building is still the live tram depott
reviews/15/text:
This is basically a large room with some old tram cars.  The video is a nice view of historic costuming.
There is no elevator and a look at the Electric Plant was of little interest. They need  enhance this museum with old time pictures or stories of the trams throughout history.
reviews/16/text:
If you intend to go, arrive by the old tram and present your ticket to gain a 30% discount.
Not interactive, only one tram was available to climb aboard. There was a TV screen with a video playing of the route the tram takes. On the upper level there are big electric things, cold war styling.
reviews/17/text: We got off the vintage tram on our way back to Porto from Foz at the museum. There is a good collection of vintage trams if transport is your interest. We then walked back into Porto along the river 30/40 minutes.
reviews/18/text: Whilst riding on the No1 Tram I spotted this as we rattled past and decided I had to go. I wasn't disappointed, the building is the former generating building for the Trams and retains much of the old machinery. The building is light and airy and very well maintained, there are around a dozen Trams all lovingly restored to their former glory. A reminder of the colourful past when these vehicles were a common sight.
reviews/19/text:
In this museum there is a plenty of Trums ( old but well Maintained), Pictures allowed but in limited Trums .Second floor present the control of the  Trum Network in Porto and Its Electricity feeding System.
Recommended for family with Kids

reviews/1/text:
This Church dedicated to St. Anthony was built on a site of a previous Chapel in 17c.
From a distance it doesn't catch your eye, as it seems incorporated in residential buildings left and right from it. However, the interiors are nice with a golden altar.
Across it is the terrific art gallery like Sao Bento train station.
reviews/1/title: Beautiful Church across the train station
reviews/2/text:
In English this means the Church of St Anthony's Congregation. It is attractively decorated with blue and white tiles and can be found just north of the main Porto Sao Bento Railway Station. 
Our walking tour of Porto with Viking River Cruises had quite a long stop at the São Bento Train Station, in part as a comfort stop.  Having seen this beautiful little church earlier and having some free time on my hands, I decided to take a look.  There was a service going on, so I just took a quick look inside with a couple of photos.  However, it was well worth the short detour.
reviews/3/text: You notice this big church as it is in the open on a big square with traffic around it.  Go inside and you will find the typical baroque decorations and all of the gild.  Important if you are doing a study of churches.
reviews/4/text:
In the center of Porto, this is the closest church and it is immediately accessible from the San Benito station and from the central Rua da Flores.
it was intended to be the seat of the Brotherhood of Saint Anthony of Lisbon. It has a Baroque style facade and the facade displays a niche with the image of Saint Anthony. Ponte de Arrabida is the first bridge from the Atlantic ocean. It's a single span arch bridge crossing the Douro river connecting Porto with Vila Nova de Gaia.
It looks like a concrete version of the iconic Dom Luis bridge without the lower level.
It's best seen from the "Six bridges cruise" which I strongly recommend as a great excursion.

reviews/4/text: Tall, spanning the two high banks of the Duero. The Arrabida Bridge is an arched bridge over the Douro River that connects Porto  with Vila Nova de Gaia. This bridge is a bridge with a reinforced cement  arch, which at the time of its construction, in 1963,  was the largest one in existence on our planet. The design and construction engineer was Edgar Antonio de Mesquita Cardoso, who collaborated with architect Inacio Peres Fernandes and engineer Jose Francisco de Azevedo e Silva. It looks great from the river. This engineering masterpiece is well worth seeing.
reviews/5/text:

reviews/10/text:
My partner and myself are lovers of fine art, beautiful furnishings and decorative period interiors.
We travel all over the world to visit Palaces, Historic Houses, Castles and unique Museums with worthy collections.
On our recent trip to Oporto we had on our must see list the fascinating CASA MUSEU de CASTRO which was left to the state by the owners family for everyone to enjoy. It was given to the Museu Nacional de Soares dos Reis to preserve, present and allow visits.
This House Museum is a 30 minute walk from the centre of Oporto so is easily accessible by foot or 15 minute metro station.
However even though the internet website stated it was open daily, on arrival we found it was never open to the general public without pre-booking and arranging a time and date direct with the SOARES dos REIS MUSEUM. Thus making a visit here almost impossible to experience without jumping over numerous fences.
(If you use the internet to look at the images of this house museum you will all see why it is so special).
This is totally unacceptable and we urge, request and plead for the owning museum to consider allowing this house museum, which has a series of the most unique interiors and furnishings in Portugal, to be open at least 1 or 2 days a week during the season for all to experience, even if it is by guided tour only in small groups of 6 people at a time.
.......In the meantime whilst the management and curatorial team at the Soares dos Reis consider this review, may I suggest to all like minded art lovers that they enjoy the limited collection of the owning museum here, and then continue to what we thought was the best collection of art, furniture, porcelain, sculpture and family treasures in Oporto at the wonderful TEIXEIRA LOPES HOUSE MUSEUM in the Gaia district just over the bridge. It is by guided tour of upto 1 and1/2 hours but is unforgettable in its period decor and was our Oporto highlight.

reviews/11/text: Located in the Carrancas Palace, the museum, named after a Portuense benefactor and sculptor, houses a great collection of 19th and 20th century Portuguese paintings, sculpture, furniture and ceramics. It is relevant for the Portuguese but probably not for foreigners, who may be less interested in Portuguese takes on French art. Unlike most European museums, this one has no English titles or descriptions, which feels totally anachronistic. All in all, I'd be happier if I visited the Navigation museum.

It’s not easy to find (very little is in Porto) but worth the effort: a seemingly small space which opens to reveal hidden treasure troves. 

All Portuguese art, mostly from those who have long passed on, so expect dour, melancholic and morose expressions - typically Iberian art. But there are gems, particularly some of the later 1900s work, exquisite sculptures, stunning jewellery, and for me as an expat Aussie, even a painting of home.
reviews/17/text: We chose to go here as a previous TripAdvisor reviewer had said it had a decent restaurant, and we thought we would combine a bit of art with a nice lunch. However, the restaurant was closed and we ended up in a cafe next door with a tourist menu and what can only be called a filling lunch, involving more cabbage than we're used to.  The building felt unloved, as other reviewers have said, but there were some lovely paintings and sculptures. The lack of English language information meant I spent a fair bit of time looking for a signal on my phone searching Wikipedia for information about the Portuguese artists and their works, which I did find and was interested to read. For example, it was sad to read of the fate of Henrique Pousao, who died of TB in his 20s. He went to Capri in the hopes his health would improve, and there are some excellent examples of his work while there.  My husband particularly liked an upstairs gallery with furniture in the French style. It is not a large gallery, so we only spent an hour viewing the paintings etc, and felt we had seen it all.

reviews/19/text:
The National Museum of Soares dos Reis is located beside Porto Central Hospital just to the east of the Crystal Palace Gardens and entrance is 5 Euros per adult.
   This is Portugal's first Art Museum (1833) and is housed in the 18th century Palace of Carrancas. The exhibition comprises of paintings, sculptures, jewellery, furniture and other objects d'art that were collected from extinct monasteries, Royal Palaces etc.
   We found that during our visit that we were the only visitors in the museum at the time so there was no problem in taking our time looking at the exhibits if we wanted to. The first section of the Palace consisted of paintings and sculptures of the highest quality especially the paintings by Henrique Pousao, I saw more works of this artist when we visited Lisbon a few days later. The second section contained jewellery, gold and silverware, glassware and ceramics demonstrating the richness and fineness of Portuguese craftsmanship.
   We thought overall that this collection was fabulous to see and wished that we had a bit more time for our visitation.
reviews/19/title: Fabulous art collection of Portugal's first Art Museum

On our visit to Matosinhos, on the Atlantic Ocean, we stopped at the Forte de São Francisco Xavier, which guarded the coast, just below Matosinhos harbor, and at the terminus of Avenida da Boavista, the primary thoroughfare between Oporto and Matosinhos. The Forte is also reachable from the city center via the Tram (Électrico).

The  Forte de São Francisco Xavier is a defensive structure, built in the mid-1600's, under a commission by King John, and is still in excellent shape, and especially so, considering that it sits on a rocky outcropping, over the vast Atlantic Ocean. That outcropping is locally referred to as Praia do Queijo – the Beach of cheese, due to the rocks’ resemblance to a block of cheese. I did not see that likeness, but cannot argue with the description – perhaps it looks different, at different times of the day? We were there fairly early on a mid-September morning, so maybe a trick of the eye, or the light? The Forte was constructed on a much earlier building site, suggested to be Celtic in origin, and dating to the 6th Century.

Entrance fee to  the Forte de São Francisco Xavier is but  €0.50, however there is no literature available, and few informational signs.

The interior is quite interesting, and well-worth a look, if for no other reason that to understand the operational aspects of an early defensive fort. There were still a few cannons in place, and the views of the Atlantic Ocean, plus the shoreline up to Matosinhos are spectacular.

This is definitely a “must-see,” and with so much around it, well-worth the effort to get out here. While one can easily spend an hour in/around the  Forte de São Francisco Xavier, and the surrounding beach, they will already be within a stone’s throw of so many interesting sites, that the trip will be greatly rewarded.
reviews/12/text:
We visited Castelo do Queijo, or Forte de São Francisco Xavier, but also just the “Castle of the Cheese” on our first full day in Oporto. Our guide/driver had circled down from Matosinhos, and its beach, and parked almost in front of the Castle, for us to explore this area. It was a bright, sunny September day, and because it was a Monday (also at the start of a taxi strike), the Castle was not crowded, nor was the beach.

We were told that the Castle/Fort got its rather peculiar name from the rock outcrop, on which it was built. It was also built on same site as a much older structure, probably also some type of fortification, from the 6th, or 7th Century. I was glad that our driver was a great tour guide, as none of that information was available at the Castle. However, with the insanely low cost of €0.50, I would not expect a lot of signs, and placards.

On the upper ramparts, there are still a few cannons, but the two prime features are the exterior architecture (built from native stone, probably quarried up the Douro River), and then the view from the Castle.

Well worth the stop, and besides, it sits on a beautiful beach!

Our guide told us the story of this knight-explorer and Captain to Henry the Navigator.  What we found more interesting than his extraordinary and heroic exploits was the issue of "ancestry."

It mattered not at all whether one was a converso or not, if the bloodline had Jewish origins, all bets were off.  The Zarco plaza in front of the fortress is named for this accomplished leader of the highest order.  But there was always the issue of his lineage.

When traveling, uncover all the rocks and explore all avenues.  It makes for a rich travel experience.  And listen to the guides.

We happened upon this museum and it almost felt like a private visit - surprising as the park it is situated next to was busy.  The displays in the rooms change periodically. 

What we saw reflected items and artefacts merchants and wealthy collectors might have possessed in the eighteenth and nineteenth centuries.  These included furnishings, textiles, ceramics and natural history specimens.  All displayed well and with English translations provided.

This is an intimate museum and not suitable for large groups.  Try and pick a quiet time to really enjoy your visit.
reviews/1/text: The pictures in this description dont reflect the current exhibition.  In the past, the aim of the Museu Romântico WAS to recreate the "Romanticism" of a wealthy residence from 19th century Porto.  In 2022, the museum was recurated.  The current exhibition has pieces from the archive of Museu da Cidade and the former Museu Municipal do Porto – Portugal’s first public museum, set up in 1848 – with origins in Museu Allen, which had pieces from the collector that showed an eclectic interest, research and curiosity, characteristic of Romanticism.  Metamorfoses: Imanência Vegetal, Mineral e Animal no Espaço Doméstico Romântico, is on view at Museu da Cidade – Extensão do Romantismo, until 31 december of 2023.   We thoroughly enjoyed the exhibits which were displayed beautifully and with wonderful descriptions.  I dont feel that children would appreciate/enjoy.
reviews/2/text: Once the last refuge of King Carlos of Piedmont and Sardinia, this 19th century mansion and estate is now home to carefully curated collections of Romanticism, up close and personal. Each room has its own theme and description with unusual artifacts: fans of the period, inlaid boxes, shell combs, textiles, and the current star: an entire room called the Cabinet of Curiosities that surprised and delighted our senses and sense of global adventure in its displays. Exhibitions change often, while the staff is committed to our understanding and enjoyment of the Romantic Period. Located on the leafy grounds of the Crystal Palace, the gardens offer a clear view of the city and an elegant upscale restaurant, Antiqvvm with classic Portuguese cuisine and regional wines--advance reservations and time needed.
